DIVISION 2. - AIRPORT ZONING BOARD 

Sec. 2-61. - Membership. 
    The city and the county hereby create a joint airport zoning board to be known as the airport zoning board, which shall consist of five (5) members whose terms of office shall be for five (5) years, and whose terms of office shall run so that each year one (1) term of office shall expire. Two (2) members of the airport zoning board shall be appointed by the city council. Two (2) members of the airport zoning board shall be appointed by the board of county commissioners. The fifth member shall be selected by a majority of the other four (4) members, and this member so selected shall serve as permanent chairman of the airport zoning board. As each term expires, the member assuming office shall be selected in the same manner as his predecessor was selected. 
(Code 1978, § 095.01) 
Sec. 2-62. - Powers; duties. 
    The airport zoning board shall have all powers and duties prescribed by applicable state law to adopt, amend from time to time, administer and enforce airport zoning regulations. 
(Code 1978, § 095.02) 
Sec. 2-63. - Adoption of regulations. 
    All proposed regulations of the airport zoning board shall be adopted in accordance with the provisions of applicable state law. 
(Code 1978, § 095.03) 
Sec. 2-64. - Enforcement of regulations. 
    Any regulation adopted by the airport zoning board may provide that a violation constitutes a misdemeanor and may seek specific enforcement by any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Code 1978, § 095.04) 
Secs. 2-65-2-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - POLICE CIVIL SERVICE COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-81. - Creation; authority. 
    The provisions of M.S.A. § 419.01 et seq. are hereby expressly accepted and adopted by the city in the creation of a police civil service commission, which shall have exclusive control and supervision over the employment, promotion, discharge and suspension of all officers and employees of the police department of the city. 
(Code 1978, § 070.01) 
Secs. 2-82-2-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - TRANSIT BOARD 

Sec. 2-101. - Established. 
    There is hereby established a transit board for the city. 
(Code 1978, § 096.01) 
Sec. 2-102. - Appointment of members. 
    The mayor shall appoint the members of the transit board, subject to the approval of five (5) members of the city council. 
(Code 1978, § 096.07) 
Sec. 2-103. - Terms of members. 
    The transit board shall be composed of five (5) members whose terms shall be for a period of three (3) years. No person shall serve as a member of the transit board for more than two (2) terms. 
(Code 1978, § 096.02) 
Sec. 2-104. - Meetings. 
    The transit board shall meet at least once each month. At the first meeting in each calendar year, the board shall establish the regular meeting date and time for the current year. 
(Code 1978, § 096.03) 
Sec. 2-105. - Officers. 
    At the first meeting in each calendar year, the transit board shall elect a chairperson and a secretary, who shall serve one-year terms. 
(Code 1978, § 096.04) 
Sec. 2-106. - Powers; duties. 
    The transit board shall have, subject to the overriding power of the council set out in section 2-107, the following powers and duties: 
(1)  It shall prepare an annual budget and submit the budget to the city council for approval. 
(2)  It shall make arrangements for the entering into of contracts by the city with funding agencies and providers. 
(3)  It shall monitor and evaluate the transit systems within the city and recommend changes in the system to the city council. 
(4)  It shall be responsible for the promotion and marketing of the transit systems of the city. 
(5)  It shall establish routes and schedules for the public conveyances operating as a part of the city transit system. 
(6)  It shall make recommendations to the city council on the rates to be charged by the public conveyances operating within the transit system. 
(7)  It shall submit a complete copy of the minutes of each meeting to the city council, the minutes to be submitted at the city council meeting next following the transit board meeting. 
(Code 1978, § 096.05) 
Sec. 2-107. - Power of council to overrule actions of board. 
    The council shall have the power to overrule, by the affirmative vote of at least five (5) members thereof, any decision, motion, resolution, rule, regulation or order of the transit board, at the council meeting next following the receipt by the city clerk-treasurer of the minutes of the board containing such action. If the council fails or refuses to overrule such action at the meeting, the action shall be absolute; provided, however, that if the council desires to consider the matter further, it may by resolution defer action on the matter for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days. No such action shall be deemed to have been presented to the council unless it shall have been included in the minutes of a duly constituted meeting of the board and the text of any resolution, rule or regulation attached thereto in full. It shall be the duty of the city clerk-treasurer to transmit such minutes, resolutions, rules and regulations to the council at the council meeting next following receipt by him thereof. 
(Code 1978, § 096.06) 
Secs. 2-108-2-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - HUMAN RIGHTS COMMISSION[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Fair housing, § 7-26 et seq. 

Sec. 2-111. - Establishment. 
    There is hereby created the human rights commission of the City of Willmar. The commission shall be composed of not more than fifteen (15) and not less than seven (7) members. All members must be residents of the city. Members shall be appointed by the mayor with the approval of the city council. Membership on another city commission or committee, city employment or the holding of another city office shall not be a bar to membership on the human rights commission. 
(Ord. No. 1049, § 1, 2-2-94) 
Sec. 2-112. - Terms. 
    Commission members shall serve for a term of three (3) years. Of the members initially appointed, one-third ( 1/3 ) shall be appointed for a term of one (1) year, one-third ( 1/3 ) shall be appointed for a term of two (2) years, and the remainder shall be appointed for a term of three (3) years. 
(Ord. No. 1049, § 2, 2-2-94) 
Sec. 2-113. - Leaves of absence. 
(a)  A commission member who will be temporarily absent from the community, or otherwise unable to attend seven (7) or more consecutive meetings of the commission or any member who has missed seven (7) or more consecutive meetings, shall submit his or her resignation from the commission. 
(b)  A commission member who, for good reason, will miss more than two (2) but less than seven (7) consecutive meetings, shall so inform the commission chairperson, and may be granted a leave of absence by the executive committee of the human rights commission. If such leave of absence is not approved by the executive committee, the member shall resign. 
(c)  If a member requested or required to resign pursuant to this subdivision does not resign, the commission may recommend to the city council that the city council remove such member and, upon majority vote of the council, such member shall be removed. 
(Ord. No. 1049, § 3, 2-2-94) 
Sec. 2-114. - Vacancies. 
    Any vacant positions may be filled for the unexpired portion of any term of the mayor with the approval of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1049, § 4, 2-2-94) 
Sec. 2-115. - Compensation. 
    Members of the commission shall serve without compensation. In the event a commissioner is a city-elected official or employee, no additional compensation shall be paid for services as a commissioner. 
(Ord. No. 1049, § 5, 2-2-94) 
Sec. 2-116. - Removal. 
    The council, by majority vote, may remove any member of the commission with or without cause. 
(Ord. No. 1049, § 6, 2-2-94) 
Sec. 2-117. - Goals. 
    The human rights commission is dedicated to eliminating illegal discrimination and remedying the impact of discrimination on the lives of the people of the city. To accomplish these goals, the commission will: 
(1)  Motivate organizations and individuals to comply with the Minnesota Human Rights Act. 
(2)  Anticipate and identify changes in the social environment that affect human and civil rights issues. 
(3)  Actively work to create and strengthen its relationship with relevant public, private and community-based organizations, in order to share information and cooperatively recognize and address emerging civil rights issues. 
(4)  Devote resources to human rights education to promote an environment free of discrimination. Whenever possible, the commission will attempt to prevent discriminatory situations from arising. 
(5)  Promote, create and maintain an environment free from discrimination. 
(6)  Maintain the confidence of the public by keeping the community informed of relevant changes pertaining to discrimination within the scope of all human rights issues. 
(Ord. No. 1049, § 7, 2-2-94) 
Sec. 2-118. - Duties. 
    In fulfillment of its purpose, the commission's duties and responsibilities shall be to: 
(1)  Adopt bylaws and rules for the conduct of its affairs including the election, assumption of duties and definition of responsibilities of officers and committees. 
(2)  Enlist the cooperation of agencies, organizations and individuals in the community in an active program directed to create equal opportunity and eliminate discrimination and inequalities. 
(3)  Formulate a human relations program for the city to give increased effectiveness and direction to the work of all individuals and agencies addressing themselves to planning, policy making and educational programming in the area of civil and human rights. 
(4)  Advise the mayor, the council and other agencies of the government of human relations and civil rights problems. Act in an advisory capacity with respect to planning or operation of any city department on issues of civil and human rights and recommend the adoption of such specific policies or actions as are needed to provide for full equal opportunity in the community. 
(5)  Develop in cooperation with the State Department of Human Rights such programs of formal and informal education as will assist in the implementation of the Minnesota Human Rights Act and provide for the commission's assumption of leadership in recognizing and resolving potential problem areas in the community. The commission shall not resolve or hear complaints or grievances between parties nor participate in the State of Minnesota Department of Human Rights No-Fault Grievance Procedure. 
(6)  Neither the commission nor any member of the commission shall make any contract, agreement or other obligation, committing the commission and/or the city to the expenditure or potential liability for the expenditure of sums. Contracts and purchases on behalf of the commission shall be made by the city administrator as the same may be approved by the city council either explicitly and/or in the adoption of a budget for the commission. 
(7)  The commission shall not have the authority to accept grants and/or donations except as specifically and explicitly approved by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1049, § 8, 2-2-94) 
Sec. 2-119. - Staff assistance. 
    The city administrator will coordinate and assign staff to assist the commission as the city administrator may deem appropriate from time to time. Commission requests for staff assistance shall be made to the city administrator. 
(Ord. No. 1049, § 9, 2-2-94) 
Sec. 2-120. - Procedures. 
(a)  The commission shall adopt rules for its operation which rules, or any changes thereof, shall not be effective until approved by the city council. The city council may itself adopt, amend or repeal any commission rule. 
(b)  The mayor, with the approval of the council, shall appoint one (1) commission member to serve as the chairperson of the commission and a vice-chairperson to serve during the absence of the chairperson. 
(c)  Meetings and operations of the commission shall be conducted in accordance with applicable laws governing public access to such meetings, operations and data. 
(Ord. No. 1049, § 10, 2-2-94) 
Secs. 2-121-2-122. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - MUNICIPAL AIRPORT COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-123. - Purpose created, composition, appointment and term of office. 
(a)  It is the intent of the Willmar City Council to provide for a municipal airport facility that operates in a safe and efficient manner while enhancing the economic viability of the community. In order to educate and inform the council and general public on aviation matters and to assist with management decisions and operations of the airport, there is hereby created and established a commission to the city council to be known and designated as the Willmar Airport Commission. 
(b)  The commission shall consist of seven (7) members appointed by the mayor with the consent of a majority of the city council. Members of the commission shall be residents of the City of Willmar. At least two (2) of the seven (7) members of the airport commission shall be licensed pilots whose primary base of operation is the Willmar Municipal Airport. 
(c)  The members shall serve terms of three (3) years, except for those initially appointed to the commission whose terms shall be staggered so that two (2) original appointees shall serve terms of one (1) year, two (2) shall serve terms of two (2) years, and three (3) shall serve terms of three (3) years. 
(d)  Commission members shall serve without remuneration for their service, but may be reimbursed for expenses incurred in the performance of commission duties. 
(Ord. No. 1113, § 1, 1-11-99; Ord. No. 1236, § 1, 5-1-06) 
Sec. 2-124. - Organization and procedure. 
(a)  At the organization meeting of the commission held in January of each year, the commission shall elect a chairperson, vice-chairperson and secretary from its membership whose term in office shall be for a period of one (1) year. 
(b)  The commission shall establish a regular time and place of meeting. All meetings shall be conducted in accordance with Roberts Rules of Order Revised. The commission may make or alter rules and regulation governing its organization and procedure in a manner not inconsistent with this Code or other ordinances of the city. 
(c)  A majority of all members of the commission shall constitute a quorum, and all business may be transacted by a majority vote of a quorum. 
(Ord. No. 1113, § 2, 1-11-99; Ord. No. 1236, § 2, 5-1-06) 
Sec. 2-125. - Duties and responsibilities. 
(a)  The commission shall serve as a recommending body to the city council concerning all improvements, maintenance, equipment and regulations. 
(b)  The commission shall develop and recommend airport operation and maintenance standards. 
(c)  Recommend an annual budget and capital improvement program in such form as required by the city council which must contain provisions for an airport manager, capital outlay, maintenance expenses, and all other expenses and income including the establishment of appropriate rental and sales charges and rates. 
(d)  Recommend and participate in promotion activities and programs, economic development, and marketing for the airport. 
(e)  Within a reasonable time after the end of each calendar year, the commission shall make a written report of its activities during the preceding year and file the report with the city administrator. The commission shall also submit to the city council minutes of each regular and special commission meeting. 
(Ord. No. 1113, § 3, 1-11-99; Ord. No. 1236, § 3, 5-1-06) 
ARTICLE IV. - ELECTIONS[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Charter reference- Nominations and elections, art. VI.

DIVISION 2. - WARDS AND PRECINCTS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Mayor and council, § 2-26 et seq. 
State Law reference- Election law, M.S.A. § 203B.01 et seq.; municipal elections, M.S.A. § 205.01 et seq. 

Sec. 2-146. - Generally. 
    The city shall be divided in four (4) wards and each ward shall be further subdivided into precincts with such boundaries as are provided in this article. 
(Code 1978, § 050.01; Ord. No. 867, § 1, 10-18-85) 
Sec. 2-147. - First Ward.
