Secs. 2-151-2-199. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SALE OF SURPLUS PROPERTY 

Sec. 2-200. - Sale of surplus property. 
(a)  Authorization to dispose of surplus equipment. City departments may sell or otherwise dispose of surplus supplies, materials and equipment pursuant to this section. Sales of surplus supplies, materials and equipment may be made at a public auction conducted annually, or as otherwise permitted by law. Nothing in this section shall require the city to sell any city-owned surplus supplies, materials, or equipment. 
(b)  Declaration of surplus property. Before the city may sell or dispose of any city-owned surplus supplies, materials, or equipment, the council shall by resolution declare such property to be surplus to the city's needs. The resolution shall include a list of the city-owned surplus supplies, materials, and equipment which will be available for sale at the public auction, and state the procedure by which such surplus property shall be auctioned, sold or otherwise disposed of consistent with applicable law. 
(c)  Authorization for the police department to dispose forfeited property. The chief of police may sell or otherwise dispose of forfeited property pursuant to the procedures set forth in Minnesota Statutes, including, but not limited to, M.S.A. § 609.5315, as the same may be amended from time to time. Such forfeited property may be included in any public auction or other sale authorized by this Section without needing to first be declared surplus pursuant to subsection (b) above. 
(d)  Purchasing requirements. Any purchaser or recipient of city-owned surplus supplies, materials, or equipment sold or disposed of under this section shall be required to execute a standard purchase agreement, in a form to be provided by the city, waiving any claims and releasing the city from any liability resulting from the purchaser's or recipient's use of the supplies, materials, or equipment after the sale or disposition. The city clerk may execute the standard purchase agreement on the city's behalf. 
(Ord. No. 1423, § 1, 8-6-18) 
Chapter 3 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses, permits and business regulations, ch. 8; use of taxicabs for transportation of intoxicating liquors prohibited, § 8-241; nuisances, ch. 9; parks and recreation, ch. 11; alcoholic beverages in public parks prohibited, § 11-88; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 13; traffic and vehicles, ch. 15. 
State Law reference- Liquor act, M.S.A. § 340A.101 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 3-1. - Definitions. 
    The words, terms and phrases used in this chapter shall have the meanings ascribed to them in the state liquor act, M.S.A. § 340A.101 et seq., except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning, or except where a different meaning is specifically provided in this chapter, in which case the meaning shall be as provided in this chapter. 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 3-2. - Selling or giving intoxicating liquor to persons to whom sale is prohibited. 
    No person shall give, sell, procure or purchase intoxicating liquor or 3.2% malt liquor to or for any person to whom the sale of intoxicating liquor is forbidden by law. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.15(1); Ord. No. 1305, § 1, 6-7-10) 
Sec. 3-3. - Preparation for consumption, consumption of intoxicating liquor in unlicensed public place. 
    No person shall mix or prepare intoxicating liquor for consumption or consume intoxicating liquor in any public place not licensed in accordance with the ordinances of the city and the state law. For purposes of this section, a public place shall mean any building or outdoor space that is open to the public with or without an admission fee. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.15(2); Ord. No. 1256, § 1, 3-19-07) 
Cross reference- Parks and recreation, ch. 11; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 13; parades and processions, § 15-181 et seq. 
Sec. 3-4. - Consumption of liquor on highway or in motor vehicle. 
(a)  No intoxicating liquor shall be consumed on a public highway or in any motor vehicle. 
(b)  No malt liquor shall be consumed on any public highway or in any motor vehicle upon any public highway. 
(Code 1978, §§ 1209.15(3), 1210.07, subd. 2) 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 15. 
Sec. 3-5. - Sale, distribution or consumption of intoxicating liquors at civic center arena. 
(a)  License required. No intoxicating liquor shall be sold, distributed or consumed at the Willmar Civic Center Arena, referred to in this section as the arena, except at a function for which a license has been granted for the service or sale of alcohol pursuant to this section. 
(b)  Application for license. The city clerk-treasurer shall prepare forms to be used in the application for a license pursuant to this section. The city clerk-treasurer shall also develop the rules and procedures for processing all such applications. 
(c)  Conditions for granting of license. A license for the service or sale of intoxicating liquors at the arena shall be granted only when the following conditions are met: 
(1)  The arena has been rented by a person, corporation, partnership, limited liability company or other lawfully organized entity, for a convention, group meeting, banquet, conference or social affair, including concerts and athletic events at which the participants' eligibility is not limited to persons eighteen (18) years of age or younger. 
(2)  The vendor of the intoxicating liquor is currently the holder of an on-sale liquor license in the city and has agreed to comply with the conditions established by the chief of police to protect the public health and safety. 
(3)  The city council has approved the granting of the license following the granting of approvals by the chief of police. 
(4)  The vendor of the intoxicating liquor shall have furnished proof of insurance coverage compliant with the following minimum requirements: 
a.  Worker's compensation coverage in statutorily required amounts. 
b.  Employees liability coverage in limits of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) per employee. 
c.  Comprehensive general liability coverage in limits of not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence for personal bodily injury and death, and limits of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for leased premises damages liability, including coverage for public liability, premises and operations liability, independent contractors-protective contingent liability, personal injury, owned, non-owned and hired vehicles. 
d.  Liquor liability (dram shop) coverage of not less than five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00). 
e.  With the exception of the worker's compensation policies, all policies listed above shall name the city as an additional insured under the policy. 
(5)  Licenses granted under this section for concerts or athletic events shall authorize the sale of intoxicating malt liquor only. 
(d)  Appeal of denial of license. Any vendor denied a license under this section shall be entitled to appeal the decision of denial to the city council. 
(e)  Duration of license. Any license granted under this section shall be limited in time to the duration of the event(s) for which the arena has been rented. 
(f)  Hours of sale. No intoxicating liquor shall be sold or distributed at the arena except on days and during hours established for the sale of on-sale liquor by M.S.A. § 340A.504. 
(g)  No individual may bring alcohol to or distribute alcohol at the arena except an individual acting on behalf of the licensed vendor specified in subparagraph (c)(3) of this section. 
(h)  Compliance with other laws. All laws of the state shall be complied with at all times and all ordinances of the city shall be complied with at all times except to the extent that such ordinances conflict with this section, in which case the provisions of this section shall prevail. 
(i)  Violation. Any person violating the terms of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 782, §§ 1-5, 5-5-82; Ord. No. 924, §§ 1-7, 5-18-88; Ord. No. 1271, § 1, 2-19-08; Ord. No. 1391, § 1, 7-5-16; Ord. No. 1421, § 1, 5-21-18) 
Cross reference- Parks and recreation, ch. 11; streets, sidewalks and other public property, ch. 13. 
State Law reference- Temporary on-sale licenses, M.S.A. § 340A.404, subd. 4. 
Sec. 3-6. - Licensing of sale of wine for on-premises consumption. 
(a)  License required. No person shall directly or indirectly deal in, sell or keep for sale any wine for on-premises consumption without first having been granted a license to do so as provided in this section. 
(b)  Eligible premises. Only restaurants with a seating capacity for at least twenty-five (25) guests, theaters with live performances and a person who is the owner of a summer collegiate league baseball team or a person holding a concessions or management contract with the owner, for beverage sales at a ballpark or stadium located within the city for the purposes of summer collegiate league baseball games at the ballpark or stadium shall be eligible for a wine license. 
(c)  Compliance with existing municipal code provisions. Applicants for wine licenses and holders of wine licenses shall comply with the following sections of this Code: 3-114; 3-115; 3-117; 3-118; 3-119; 3-120; 3-121; 3-122; 3-123; 3-124; 3-125; 3-126; 3-127; 3-128; 3-129; 3-130; 3-132; 3-133; 3-134; 3-135; 3-151 through 3-155; 3-76 through 3-92. 
(d)  Fee. The fee for a wine license shall be in such amount as is from time to time established by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1053, §§ 1-4, 4-20-94; Ord. No. 1301, § 1, 12-21-09; Ord. No. 1318, § 1, 6-6-11) 
Sec. 3-7. - Issuance of license prohibited to delinquent persons or entities. 
    No person or entity shall be issued an on-sale or off-sale intoxicating liquor or non-intoxicating liquor license if such person or entity is delinquent in payment to the city of any fees or charges assessed by the city or by the Willmar Municipal Utilities Commission. In addition, no such license shall be issued to any premises for which there are delinquent real estate taxes or delinquent assessments. 
(Ord. No. 1058, § 1, 9-7-94) 
Cross reference- Application for off-premises license, § 3-47; persons eligible for on-premises license, § 3-114; persons eligible for non-intoxicating malt liquor license, § 3-229. 
Sec. 3-8. - Residency requirement. 
(a)  All on sale and off sale intoxicating liquor licensees shall either have a permanent residence in Kandiyohi County or have a general manager fully authorized to act for and on behalf of the licensee that is a permanent resident of Kandiyohi County. At least one (1) of the general partners of a licensee shall be a permanent resident of Kandiyohi County or the partnership shall have a general manager fully authorized to act for and on behalf of the partnership that is a permanent resident of Kandiyohi County. Each corporate licensee shall have a general manager fully authorized to act for and on behalf of the corporation that is a permanent resident of Kandiyohi County. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, a permanent resident is a person who resides in Kandiyohi County twelve (12) months of each calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 1065, §§ 1, 2, 6-7-95) 
Sec. 3-9. - Conditions by which restaurants may sell intoxicating malt liquor at on-sale without additional license. 
    Any restaurant that has a current wine license pursuant to section 3-6 and a current on-sale license to sell non-intoxicating malt liquor issued pursuant to section 3-223, may also sell intoxicating malt liquor at on-sale without an additional license being issued, provided, at least sixty (60) percent of the gross receipts of the restaurant are attributable to the sale of food. 
(Ord. No. 1076, § 1, 5-15-96) 
Sec. 3-10. - [Minimum penalties for violations of state or city ordinances resulting from the sale of alcoholic beverages.] 
(a)  Definition of alcoholic beverages. For purposes of this section, alcoholic beverages shall mean three and two-tenths (3.2) percent malt liquors and intoxicating liquors as those terms are defined in M.S.A. § 340A.101. 
(b)  Minimum penalties for violations. The minimum penalties for violations of Minnesota State laws or city ordinances resulting from the sale of alcoholic beverages shall be as follows: 
(1)  First violation. A written warning to the license holder and an appearance at a regularly scheduled city council committee meeting by the license holder to explain to the council measures being taken by the license holder to eliminate future violations of the ordinances and statutes regulating the sale of alcoholic beverages. 
(2)  Second violation. One thousand dollars ($1,000.00) fine. 
(3)  Third violation. Two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) fine. 
(4)  Fourth violation. Three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) fine. 
(5)  Fifth and subsequent violations. Referred to full city council for consideration. 
(c)  Application of section. This section shall apply to all holders of licenses for the sale of alcoholic beverages at on sale or off sale in the city. 
(d)  Establishment of greater penalty. The city council may impose a greater penalty than the minimum established in subsection (b) when there is more than one (1) violation during the same incident, or when the council determines that the minimum penalty is not a sufficient penalty because of the nature of the violation or other relevant factors justifying a greater penalty. 
(e)  Amortization of status of accumulated violations. When a license holder has not had a violation for three (3) consecutive years or when a license holder has successfully passed three (3) consecutive compliance checks, whichever time period is shorter, the violation level drops one level and each subsequent successful compliance check drops one additional level. 
(f)  Compliance with liquor laws and ordinances. The city's police department shall monitor compliance with liquor laws and ordinances by periodically conducting compliance checks on all license holders. 
(g)  Notification to license holder. The chief of police shall notify the city clerk when any license holder has violated either state law or city ordinance while selling alcoholic beverages. The city clerk shall then notify the license holder of the specific violation and the penalty as established in this section. The license holder shall have seven (7) calendar days from the date of receipt of the notice from the city clerk to request a hearing. If a hearing is not requested, the fine shall be paid within ten (10) days after expiration of the seven-day period. If a license holder shall request a hearing, the city council shall conduct a hearing as to the implementation of the fine established in this section. Any fine shall be paid within ten (10) days of the date of ratification of the fine by the city council Notice of the violation shall be mailed by first class mail, postage prepaid, or hand delivered to the manager of the license holder as named in the annual application for renewal or issuance of the license held by the violating party. 
(h)  No person shall directly or indirectly sell alcoholic beverages without first attending an alcohol servers training program approved by the chief of police. The training program is offered at intervals that may require attendance after an employee's hire date and, accordingly, new hires are required to attend within ninety (90) days after the initial hire date. All servers must attend an additional training class within ninety (90) days of each three-year anniversary date of their initial hire. 
(Ord. No. 1147, §§ 1-8, 7-2-01; Ord. No. 1320, §§ 1-7, 7-5-11) 
Secs. 3-11-3-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SALE OF INTOXICATING LIQUOR FOR OFF-PREMISES CONSUMPTION 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 3-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    License means an off-sale license issued pursuant to division 2 of this article. 
    Licensee means the holder of an off-sale license issued pursuant to division 2 of this article. 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 3-27. - Right of entry. 
    Any peace officer or any other designated officer or employee of the city shall have the unqualified right to enter, inspect and search the premises of a licensee during business hours, without a warrant. 
(Code 1978, § 1207.07(8)) 
Sec. 3-28. - Insurance. 
    Every licensee shall procure liability insurance pursuant to state law to cover its exposure to claims arising out of the negligence or violation of law by its agents or employees. 
(Code 1978, § 1207.03, subd. IV) 
Sec. 3-29. - Enlargement, alteration, or extension of premises. 
    Any proposed enlargement, alteration or extension of licensed premises shall be reported to the city council at or before the time application is made for a building permit for such change, and the licensee shall also give such information as is required by section 3-47. 
(Code 1978, § 1207.10) 
Sec. 3-30. - Hours and days of sale. 
    No sale of intoxicating liquor shall be made on any licensed premises except in accordance with the hours and days of sale specified in M.S.A. § 340A.504. 
(Code 1978, § 1207.08) 
Sec. 3-31. - Gambling. 
    No licensee shall keep, possess or operate, or permit the keeping, possession or operation of any slot machine, dice, or any gambling device or apparatus on the licensed premises or in any room adjoining the licensed premises, and he shall not permit any gambling therein. 
(Code 1978, § 1207.07(6)) 
Secs. 3-32-3-45. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Licenses required, M.S.A. § 340A.405. 

Sec. 3-46. - Authority to issue. 
    The city council shall be authorized to issue off-sale licenses to exclusive liquor stores, which shall permit the sale of liquor for off-premises consumption only, and such license is hereby required. 
(Code 1978, § 1207.02) 
Sec. 3-47. - Application. 
(a)  Every application for a license shall be verified and filed with the city clerk-treasurer. The application shall state the name of the applicant, the nature of the business making application, the time of its existence, the location of the business and such other information as the city council may require from time to time. Such application shall be in the form prescribed by the liquor control commissioner of the state. 
(b)  In addition to the information required by the state liquor control commissioner's form, the application shall contain the following: 
(1)  Information as to whether the applicant is a natural person, corporation, partnership, or other form of organization. 
(2)  If the applicant is a natural person, the following: 
a.  The true name, place and date of birth, and street residence address of the applicant. 
b.  Whether the applicant has ever used or been known by a name other than his true name and, if so, what was such name, and information concerning the dates and places where used. 
c.  The name of the business if it is to be conducted under a designation, name or style other than the full individual name of the applicant. In such case a copy of the certification, as required by M.S.A. ch. 333, certified by the clerk of district court, shall be attached to the application. 
d.  Whether the applicant is married or single, and if married, the true name, place and date of birth and street residence address of the applicant's present spouse. 
e.  Whether the applicant and his present spouse are registered voters and, if so, where. 
f.  The street address at which the applicant and his spouse have lived during the preceding ten (10) years. 
g.  The kind, name and location of every business or occupation the applicant and his spouse have been engaged in during the preceding ten (10) years. 
h.  The names and addresses of the applicant's and his spouse's employers and partners, if any, for the preceding ten (10) years. 
i.  Whether the applicant or his spouse, or a parent, brother, sister or child of the applicant or his spouse has ever been convicted of any felony, crime or violation of any ordinance other than traffic ordinances. If so, the applicant shall furnish information as to the time, place and offense for which convictions were had. 
j.  Whether the applicant or his spouse, or a parent, brother, sister or child of the applicant or his spouse has been engaged as an employee or in operating a saloon, hotel, restaurant, cafe, tavern or other business of a similar nature. If so, the applicant shall furnish information as to the time, place and length of time. 
k.  Whether the applicant has ever been in military service. If so, the applicant shall, upon request, exhibit all discharges. 
l.  The name, address and business address of each person who is engaged in the state in the business of selling, manufacturing or distributing intoxicating liquor and who is nearer of kin to the applicant or his spouse than second cousin, whether of the whole or half blood, computed by the rules of civil law, or who is a brother-in-law or sister-in-law of the applicant or his spouse. 
(3)  If the applicant is a partnership, the names and addresses of all partners and all information concerning each partner is as required of a single application in subsection (b)(2) of this section. A managing partner shall be designated. The interest of each partner in the business shall be disclosed. A true copy of the partnership agreement shall be submitted with the application. If the partnership is required to file a certificate as to the trade name under the provisions of M.S.A. ch. 333, a copy of such certificate, certified by the clerk of the district court, shall be attached to the application. 
(4)  If the applicant is a corporation or other organization, the following: 
a.  Name and, if incorporated, the state of incorporation. 
b.  A true copy of the certificate of incorporation, articles of incorporation or association agreement and bylaws and, if a foreign corporation, a certificate of authority as described in M.S.A. ch. 303. 
c.  The name of the manager or proprietor or other agent in charge of the premises to be licensed, giving all the information about the person as is required of a single applicant in subsection (b)(2) of this section. 
d.  The application shall contain a list, if required by the city council, of all persons who, singly or together with their spouse or a parent, brother, sister or child of either the person or spouse, own or control any interest in the corporation or association, together with their addresses and all information as is required of a single applicant in subsection (b)(2) of this section. 
(5)  The exact legal description of the premises to be licensed together with a plot plan of the area showing dimensions, location of buildings, street access, parking facilities and the locations of and distances to the nearest church building and school grounds. 
(6)  The floor number and street number where the sale of intoxicating liquors is to be conducted. 
(7)  If a permit from the federal government is required by the laws of the United States, whether or not such permit has been issued and, if so required, in what name issued and the nature of the permit. 
(8)  The amount of the investment that the applicant has in the business, building, premises, fixtures, furniture and stock in trade, and proof of the source of such money. 
(9)  The names and addresses of all persons other than the applicant who have any financial interest in the business, building, premises, fixtures, furniture, or stock in trade; and the nature of such interest, amount thereof, and terms for payment or other reimbursement. This shall include, but not be limited to, any lessees, lessors, mortgages, mortgagors, lenders, lienholders, trustees, trustors, and persons who have consigned notes or otherwise loaned, pledged or extended security for any indebtedness of the applicant. 
(10)  The names, residences and business addresses of three (3) persons of good moral character, not related to the applicant or financially interested in the premises or business, who may testify as to the applicant's character or, in the case where information is required of a manager, the manager's character. 
(11)  Whether or not all real estate and personal property taxes for the premises to be licensed have been paid and, if not paid, the years for which delinquent. 
(12)  Whenever the application for an off-sale license to sell intoxicating liquor, or for a transfer thereof, is for premises either planned or under construction or undergoing substantial alteration, the application shall be accompanied by a set of preliminary plans showing the design of the proposed premises to be licensed. If the plans or design are on file with the building inspector, no plans need to be filed with the city clerk-treasurer. 
(13)  Such other information as the city council shall require. 
(14)  A release authorizing the city to obtain all financial information that may be appropriate. 
(c)  No person shall make a false statement in an application. 
(Code 1978, § 1207.03, subds. I, V) 
Cross reference- Issuance of license prohibited to deliquent persons or entities. 
Sec. 3-48. - License fee. 
(a)  Receipt to accompany application. Each application for a license shall be accompanied by a receipt from the city clerk-treasurer for payment of the required fee for the license. 
(b)  Amount. The annual fee for off-sale licenses shall be in such amount as kept on file in the office of the city clerk-treasurer. The fee for a license granted after the commencement of the license year shall be prorated on a monthly basis, with each part of a month constituting a full month. 
(c)  Payment. The license fee shall be paid upon application. All fees shall be paid into the general fund of the city, and shall be paid in cash or by certified check. 
(d)  Refund prior to issuance of license. Upon rejection of any application for a license, or upon withdrawal of an application before approval of the issuance by the city council, the license fee shall be refunded to the applicant, except where rejection is for a willful misstatement in the license application. 
(e)  Failure to pay. Failure to pay any portion of a fee when due shall be cause for revocation. 
(Code 1978, § 1207.04, subds. I, III; Ord. No. 947, § 1, 4-19-89; Ord. No. 1349, § 1, 8-5-13) 
Sec. 3-49. - Investigating fee. 
(a)  At the time of each original application for a license the applicant shall pay in full an investigating fee in an amount as kept on file at the office of the city clerk-treasurer. No investigating fee shall be refunded. 
(b)  At any time when an additional investigation is required because of a change in the ownership or control of a corporation, or because of an enlargement, alteration or extension of the premises previously licensed, the licensee shall pay an additional investigating fee in an amount as kept on file at the office of the city clerk-treasurer. 
(Code 1978, § 1207.03, subd. VI) 
State Law reference- Authority to charge additional fee above that provided for in M.S.A. § 340A.408, subd. 3, ch. 781, Laws of Minn., 1967. 
Sec. 3-50. - Places ineligible to be licensed. 
    No license shall be granted for premises within three hundred (300) feet of any school. In determining this distance, measurement shall be from the nearest door of the premises to be licensed to the nearest door of any school. 
(Code 1978, § 1207.07(2); Ord. No. 1074, § 1, 2-7-96) 
Sec. 3-51. - Area of effect. 
    No license shall be effective beyond the compact and contiguous space, named in the license, for which the license was granted. 
(Code 1978, § 1207.07(3)) 
Sec. 3-52. - Posting. 
    The license shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the licensed premises at all times. 
(Code 1978, § 1207.07(1)) 
Sec. 3-53. - Transfer. 
(a)  Approval required. Each license shall be issued to the applicant only. Each license shall be issued for the premises described in the application and no license may be transferred to another person or to another place without the approval of the city council. 
(b)  Refund, payment of fees. Upon transfer of a license to another person or to another place as provided in subsection (a) of this section, no part of the license fee paid by the transferror shall be refunded. No new license fee shall be charged to the transferee, but the transferee shall pay to the city an amount as kept on file at the office of the city clerk-treasurer to defray cost of investigation by the police department of the transferee's application for the transfer of the license. 
(Code 1978, §§ 1207.04, subd. IV, 1207.05) 
State Law reference- Transfer, M.S.A. § 340A.412, subds. 2(b), 9. 
Sec. 3-54. - Expiration. 
    All licenses shall expire on April 25 of each year. Each license shall be issued for a period of one (1) year. 
(Code 1978, § 1207.04, subd. II) 
Sec. 3-55. - Refund of fees on termination of sales. 
    Any person holding an off-sale license for a period of more than three (3) consecutive years shall be entitled to a refund of the current year's license fee upon forfeiture of the license to the city clerk-treasurer and the termination of the sale of off-sale liquor. The refund shall be prorated on a monthly basis and each part of a month shall constitute a full month's usage of the license. No refund shall be made to any person who is shown by the records of the county treasurer or county auditor to be delinquent in payment of real estate taxes or to a person who is delinquent in payments to the municipal utilities commission of the city or delinquent on any other obligations owed to the city or its subdivisions. This section shall not apply to any licenseholder whose license to operate has been revoked. The condition requiring three (3) years of consecutive licensing shall not apply to any licenseholder whose place of business is taken by any governmental agency by authority of the power of eminent domain. 
(Code 1978, § 1207.04, subd. V) 
Sec. 3-56. - Revocation. 
    The council may suspend or revoke, pursuant to M.S.A. § 340A.415, a liquor license, for violation of any provision or condition of this chapter or any state law or ordinance of the city. 
(Code 1978, § 1207.09) 
Sec. 3-57. - Submission of information to liquor control commissioner. 
    The city clerk-treasurer shall, within ten (10) days after the issuance of any license under this division, submit to the liquor control commissioner the full name and address of each organization granted a license, the effective license date, and the date of expiration of the license. He shall also submit to the liquor control commissioner any change of address, transfer, cancellation or revocation of any license by the council during the license period. 
(Code 1978, § 1207.06) 
Sec. 3-58. - Off-sale malt liquor licenses. 
    A brewer licensed under M.S.A. § 340A.301, subd. 6(d), (i), or (j) may be licensed for the off-sale of malt liquor produced and packaged on the licensed premises in accordance with M.S.A. § 340A.301, subd. 7(b), subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  The annual license fee for an off-sale malt liquor license, as established in the fee schedule kept on file in the office of the city clerk-treasurer, shall be paid. 
(2)  The investigating fee established in section 3-49 of this Code shall be paid. 
(3)  Off-sale of malt liquor may only be made during the hours that off-sale of liquor may be made. 
(4)  The malt liquor shall be packaged in sixty-four-ounce containers commonly known as "growlers" or in seven hundred fifty (750) milliliter bottles. 
(5)  The malt liquor sold at off-sale must be removed from the licensed premise before the applicable closing time at exclusive liquor stores. 
(6)  The growler must be sealed in such a manner that the seal must be broken in order to open the container and the seal must bear the name and address of the brewer, and the legend "Not for Consumption in Public" must be prominently displayed on the seal. 
(7)  All other provisions of this article shall be applicable to such licenses and licensees unless inconsistent with the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 1349, § 3, 8-5-13) 
Secs. 3-59-3-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SALE OF INTOXICATING LIQUOR FOR ON-PREMISES CONSUMPTION[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- On-sale licenses, M.S.A. § 340A.404. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 3-76. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    License means an on-sale license issued pursuant to division 2 of this article. 
    Licensee means a person holding an on-sale license issued pursuant to division 2 of this article. 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 3-77. - Right of entry. 
    Any police officer, building inspector, or any other designated officer or employee of the city shall have the unqualified right to enter, inspect and search the premises of a licensee during business hours, without a warrant. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.11(11)) 
Sec. 3-78. - Right to inspect business records. 
    The business records of a licensee, including federal and state tax returns, shall be available for inspection by authorized representatives of the city or the city council at all reasonable times. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.11(16)) 
Sec. 3-79. - Enlargement, alteration or extension of premises. 
    Any proposed enlargement, alteration or extension of licensed premises shall be reported to the city council at or before the time application is made for a building permit for such change, and the licensee shall also give such information as is required by section 3-115. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.19) 
Sec. 3-80. - Licensee to be responsible for conduct of business. 
    Every licensee shall be responsible for the conduct of his place of business and the conditions of sobriety and order in the place of business and on the premises. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.11(3)) 
Sec. 3-81. - Tampering with contents of original package. 
    No licensee shall sell, offer for sale, or keep for sale, intoxicating liquors in any original package which has been refilled or partly refilled. No licensee shall directly or through any other person delete or in any manner tamper with the contents of any original package so as to change its composition or alcoholic content while in the original package. Possession on the premises by the licensee of an intoxicating liquor in the original package differing in composition or alcoholic content in the liquor when received from the manufacturer or wholesaler from whom it was purchased shall be prima facie evidence that the contents of the original package have been diluted, changed or tampered with. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.11) 
Sec. 3-82. - Keeping, use of ethyl alcohol, neutral spirits. 
    No licensee shall keep ethyl alcohol or neutral spirits on any licensed premises or permit their use on the premises as a beverage or mixed with a beverage. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.11(15)) 
Sec. 3-83. - Hours and days of sale. 
    No sale of intoxicating liquor shall be made on any licensed premises except in accordance with the days of sale specified in M.S.A. § 340A.504. No sale may be made between 1:00 a.m. and 8:00 a.m. on the days of Monday through Saturday nor after 1:00 a.m. on Sundays, except sale after 1:00 a.m. on Sundays shall be allowed by those holding a Sunday license between the hours of 10:00 a.m. on Sundays to 1:00 a.m. on Mondays. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.12; Ord. No. 1184, § 1, 8-4-03; Ord. No. 1195, § 1, 4-5-04) 
Cross reference- On-sale liquor on Sundays, § 3-136. 
Sec. 3-84. - Display of liquor during hours when sale is prohibited. 
    No on-sale liquor establishment shall display liquor to the public during hours when the sale of liquor is prohibited by this chapter. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.11(13)) 
Sec. 3-85. - Premises to be vacated after time that liquor sales must stop. 
    The licensee shall have all persons, except employees, vacate the part of the licensee's premises where liquor is sold within one-half hour of the time that liquor sales must stop as provided by M.S.A. § 340A.504. For purposes of this section, the term "premises" shall not include a private room in a motel or hotel which is rented for and being used for overnight sleeping accommodations. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.11(20); Ord. No. 848, § 2, 3-6-85; Ord. No. 885, § 1, 9-3-86) 
Sec. 3-86. - Sale for off-premises consumption. 
    No on-sale licensee shall sell intoxicating liquor for off-premises consumption. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.11(4)) 
Sec. 3-87. - Selling or furnishing liquor to certain persons. 
    No intoxicating liquor or 3.2% malt liquor shall be sold or furnished or delivered by any licensee to any intoxicated person, any habitual drunkard, any person under twenty-one (21) years of age, or any person to whom sale is prohibited by state law. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.11(6); Ord. No. 1305, § 2, 6-7-10) 
Sec. 3-88. - Permitting use of premises or adjoining buildings by prostitutes. 
    No licensee shall knowingly permit the licensed premises or any room in those premises or any adjoining building directly or indirectly under his control to be used as a resort for prostitutes. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.11) 
Sec. 3-89. - Gambling. 
    No licensee shall keep, possess, or operate or permit the keeping, possession or operation of any slot machine, dice, or any gambling device or apparatus on the licensed premises. The licensee shall not permit any gambling therein except as provided by this section. Gambling shall be permitted on a licensed premises if conducted by an organization that is exempted by M.S.A. § 349.214, subd. 2, from obtaining a gambling license or, if not so exempted, that has been licensed to conduct gambling on the licensed premises. The gambling conducted in accordance with this section shall only be the type permitted by M.S.A. § 349.11 et seq. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.11(8); Ord. No. 885, § 1, 9-3-86; Ord. No. 953, § 1, 7-5-89) 
Cross reference- Gambling establishments, § 8-291 et seq. 
State Law reference- Bingo, gambling devices and video games, M.S.A. § 349.11 et seq.; exemptions, M.S.A. § 349.214. 
Sec. 3-90. - Portion of business to be derived from serving of food. 
(a)  A restaurant shall be conducted in such a manner that a substantial part of the business for a license year is the serving of food. 
(b)  A hotel or motel shall be conducted in such a manner that, of that part of the total business attributable to or derived from the serving of foods and intoxicating liquors, the principal part of the business for a license year is the serving of food. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.11(19); Ord. No. 764, § 1, 10-7-81) 
Sec. 3-91. - Ownership of equipment by manufacturer or distiller of intoxicating liquor. 
    No equipment or fixture in any licensed place shall be owned in whole or in part by any manufacturer or distiller of intoxicating liquor, except such as shall be expressly permitted by state law. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.11(10)) 
Sec. 3-92. - Applying for, possessing federal wholesale liquor dealers stamp or gambling stamp. 
    No licensee shall apply for or possess a federal wholesale liquor dealers special tax stamp or a federal gambling stamp. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.11(14)) 
Sec. 3-93. - Prohibited activities in premises of on-sale liquor licensees. 
    No on-sale liquor licensee shall permit boxing, wrestling, ultimate fight contests, tough person contests, mixed martial arts contests or any other contest regulated by the Minnesota State Boxing Commission to be conducted on the licensed premises. For purposes of this section, on-sale liquor licensee shall include holders of on-sale intoxicating liquor licenses; on-sale wine licenses; and on-sale non-intoxicating liquor licenses. 
(Ord. No. 1267, § 1, 8-20-07) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 1267, § 1, adopted August 20, 2007, did not specifically amend the Code. Therefore, such ordinance has been added as § 3-93 at the editor's discretion. 
Secs. 3-94-3-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 3-111. - Required. 
    No person, except wholesalers or manufacturers to the extent authorized under a state license, shall directly or indirectly deal in, sell or keep for sale any intoxicating liquor for on-premises sale without first having received a license to do so as provided in this division. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.02(1)) 
Sec. 3-112. - Use. 
    Licenses issued under this division shall be for on-premises sales only. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.02(1)) 
Sec. 3-113. - Businesses eligible for license. 
    On-sale licenses shall only be issued to hotels, motels, restaurants and bowling centers. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.02(1); Ord. No. 1215, § 1, 5-2-05) 
Sec. 3-114. - Persons eligible for license. 
(a)  No license shall be granted to or held by any person: 
(1)  Not a citizen of the United States or a resident alien. 
(2)  Under twenty-one (21) years of age. 
(3)  Who has had an intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating liquor license revoked within five (5) years of the license application, or to any person who at the time of the violation owns any interest, whether as a holder of more than five (5) percent of the capital stock of a corporation licensee, as a partner or otherwise, in the premises or in the business conducted thereon, or to a corporation, partnership, association, enterprise, business, or firm in which any such person is in any manner interested. 
(4)  Not of good moral character and repute. 
(5)  Who is a manufacturer or wholesaler of intoxicating liquor. No manufacturer or wholesaler shall either directly or indirectly own or control or have any financial interest in any retail business selling intoxicating liquor. 
(6)  Who, if a corporation, does not have a manager who is eligible under the provisions of this section. 
(7)  Who is the spouse of a person ineligible for a license under the provisions of subsection (3), (5) or (6) of this section or who, in the judgment of the city council, is not the real party in interest or beneficial owner of the business operated or to be operated under the license. 
(b)  In addition, no new retail license may be issued and the city may refuse to renew the license of a person who within the past five (5) years of the license application has been convicted of a willful violation of a federal or state law or local ordinance governing the manufacture, sale, distribution or possession for sale or distribution of an alcoholic beverage. 
(c)  The term "interest," as used in this section, includes a pecuniary interest in the ownership, operation, management or profits of a retail liquor establishment, but does not include bona fide loans; bona fide fixed sum rental arrangements; bona fide open accounts or other obligations held with or without security arising out of the ordinary and regular course of business or selling or leasing merchandise, fixtures or supplies to such establishment; or an interest of ten (10) percent or less in any corporation holding a license. A person who receives monies from time to time, directly or indirectly, from a licensee, in the absence of a bona fide consideration therefor and excluding bona fide gifts or donations, shall be deemed to have a pecuniary interest in such retail license. In determining "bona fide," the reasonable value of the goods or things received as consideration for any payment by the licensee and all other facts reasonably tending to prove or disprove the existence of any purposeful scheme or arrangement to evade the prohibitions of this section shall be considered. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.09; Ord. No. 809, § 1, 8-3-83; Ord. No. 1342, § 1, 3-4-13) 
State Law reference- Persons eligible for a license, M.S.A. § 304A.402. 
Sec. 3-115. - Application. 
(a)  Every application for an on-sale license to sell intoxicating liquor shall be verified and filed with the city clerk-treasurer. 
(b)  In addition to the information which may be required by the state liquor control commissioner's form, the application shall contain the following: 
(1)  Information as to whether the applicant is a natural person, corporation, partnership or other form of organization. 
(2)  If the applicant is a natural person, the following: 
a.  The true name, place and date of birth, and street residence address of the applicant. 
b.  Whether the applicant has ever used or been known by a name other than his true name and, if so, what was such name, and information concerning the dates and places where used. 
c.  The name of the business if it is to be conducted under a designation, name or style other than the full individual name of the applicant. In such case a copy of the certification, as required by M.S.A. ch. 333, certified by the clerk of the district court, shall be attached to the application. 
d.  Whether the applicant is married or single, and if married, the true name, place and date of birth and street residence address of the applicant's spouse. 
e.  The street address at which the applicant and his spouse have lived during the preceding ten (10) years. 
f.  The kind, name and location of every business or occupation the applicant and his spouse have been engaged in during the preceding ten (10) years. 
g.  The names and addresses of the applicant's and his spouse's employers and partners, if any, for the preceding ten (10) years. 
h.  Whether the applicant or his spouse, or a parent, brother, sister or child of the applicant or his spouse, has ever been convicted of any felony, crime or violation of any ordinance other than traffic ordinances. If so, the applicant shall furnish information as to the time, place and offense for which convictions were had. 
i.  Whether the applicant or his spouse, or a parent, brother, sister or child of the applicant or his spouse has been engaged as an employee or in operating a saloon, hotel, restaurant, cafe, tavern or other business of a similar nature. If so, the applicant shall furnish information as to the time, place and length of time. 
j.  Whether the applicant has ever been in military service. If so, the applicant shall, upon request, exhibit all discharges. 
k.  The name, address and business address of each person who is engaged in the state in the business of selling, manufacturing or distributing intoxicating liquor and who is nearer of kin to the applicant or his spouse than second cousin, whether of the whole or half blood, computed by the rules of civil law, or who is a brother-in-law or sister-in-law of the applicant. 
(3)  If the applicant is a partnership, the names and addresses of all partners and all information concerning each partner is as required of a single application in subsection (b)(2) of this section. A managing partner shall be designated. The interest of each partner in the business shall be disclosed. A true copy of the partnership agreement shall be submitted with the application. If the partnership is required to file a certificate as to trade name under the provisions of M.S.A. ch. 333, a copy of such certificate, certified by the clerk of the district court, shall be attached to the application. 
(4)  If the applicant is a corporation or other organization, the following: 
a.  Name and, if incorporated, the state of incorporation. 
b.  A true copy of the certificate of incorporation, articles of incorporation or association agreement and bylaws and, if a foreign corporation, a certificate of authority as described in M.S.A. ch. 303. 
c.  The name of the manager or proprietor or other agent in charge of the premises to be licensed, giving all the information about the person as is required of a single applicant subsection (b)(2) of this section. 
d.  Notwithstanding the definition of interest as given in section 3-114(b), the application shall contain a list, if required by the city council, of all persons who, singly or together with their spouse or a parent, brother, sister or child of either the person or spouse, own or control any interest in the corporation or association, together with their addresses and all information as is required of a single applicant in subsection (b)(2) of this section. 
(5)  The exact legal description of the premises to be licensed together with a plot plan of the area showing dimensions, location of buildings, street access, parking facilities and the locations of and distances to the nearest church building and school grounds. 
(6)  The floor number and street number where the sale of intoxicating liquors is to be conducted and the rooms where liquor is to be sold or consumed. An applicant for an on-sale license shall submit a floor plan of the dining rooms that will be open to the public, which shall show dimensions and shall indicate the number of persons intended to be served in each of the rooms. 
(7)  If a permit from the federal government is required by the laws of the United States, whether or not such permit has been issued and, if so required, in what name issued and the nature of the permit. 
(8)  The amount of the investment that the applicant has in the business, building, premises, fixtures, furniture and stock in trade, and proof of the source of such money. 
(9)  The names and addresses of all persons other than the applicant who have any financial interest in the business, building, premises, fixtures, furniture, or stock in trade; and the nature of such interest, amount thereof, and terms for payment or other reimbursement. This shall include, but not be limited to, any lessees, lessors, mortgagees, mortgagors, lenders, lienholders, trustees, trustors, and persons who have cosigned notes or otherwise loaned, pledged or extended security for any indebtedness of the applicant. 
(10)  The names, residences and business addresses of three (3) residents of the county, not related to the applicant or financially interested in the premises or business, who may testify as to the applicant's character or, in the case where information is required of a manager, the manager's character. 
(11)  Whether or not all real estate and personal property taxes for the premises to be licensed have been paid and, if not paid, the years for which delinquent. 
(12)  Whenever the application for an on-sale license to sell intoxicating liquor, or for a transfer thereof, is for premises either planned or under construction or undergoing substantial alteration, the application shall be accompanied by a set of preliminary plans showing the design of the proposed premises to be licensed. If the plans or design are on file with the building inspector, no plans need be filed with the city clerk-treasurer. 
(13)  Such other information as the city council shall require. 
(14)  A release authorizing the city to obtain all financial information that may be appropriate. 
(c)  If the application is by a natural person, it shall be signed and sworn to by such person; if by a corporation, by an officer thereof; if by a partnership, by one (1) of the partners; and if by an unincorporated association, by the manager or managing officer thereof. If the applicant is a partnership, the application, license, bond and insurance policy shall be made and issued in the name of all partners. 
(Code 1978, §§ 1209.03, 1209.04, 1209.06) 
Sec. 3-116. - Insurance. 
(a)  At the time of filing an application for a license, the applicant shall file a liability insurance policy pursuant to state law or, in lieu thereof, shall deposit cash or United States government bonds which shall be deposited with the city clerk-treasurer. 
(b)  The deposit or insurance policies required by subsection (a) of this section shall be subject to the approval of the city attorney. 
(c)  The insurer on such liability insurance policy shall be an insurance company licensed to do business in the state. The liability insurance policy shall be approved as to form and execution by the city attorney. All liability insurance policies, when approved by the proper city or state officers, shall be deposited with the city clerk-treasurer. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.16(1), (2), (4)) 
Sec. 3-117. - License fee-Generally. 
(a)  Amount. The annual license fee for an on-sale license shall be in such amount as kept on file in the office of the city clerk-treasurer. The fee for a license granted after the commencement of the license year shall be prorated on a monthly basis, with each part of a month constituting a full month. 
(b)  Payment. All of the license fee shall be paid upon application. All fees shall be paid into the general fund of the city and shall be paid in cash or by certified check. 
(c)  Refund prior to issuance of license. Upon rejection of any application for a license, or upon withdrawal of an application before approval of the issuance by the city council, the license fee shall be refunded to the applicant, except where rejection is for a willful misstatement in the license application. 
(d)  Failure to pay. Failure to pay any portion of a fee when due shall be cause for revocation. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.07(1), (2); Ord. No. 1349, § 2, 8-5-13) 
Sec. 3-118. - Same-Application filed as result of incorporation. 
    Where a new application is filed as a result of incorporation by an existing licensee and the ownership control and interest in the license are unchanged, no additional license fee will be required. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.07(7)) 
Sec. 3-119. - Same-Premises not ready for occupancy. 
    When the license is for premises where the building is not ready for occupancy, the time fixed for computation of the license fee for the initial license period shall be the date the building is ready for occupancy. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.07(3)) 
Sec. 3-120. - Investigating fee. 
(a)  At the time of each original application for a license, the applicant shall pay in full an investigating fee in an amount as kept on file in the office of the city clerk-treasurer. No investigating fee shall be refunded. 
(b)  At any time that an additional investigation is required because of a change in the ownership or control of a corporation or because of an enlargement, alteration, or extension of premises previously licensed, the licensee shall pay an additional investigating fee in an amount as kept on file in the office of the city clerk-treasurer. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.07(5), (6)) 
Sec. 3-121. - Liquor committee. 
    In order to assist the city council in investigating the facts set out in the license application, and in order to determine the eligibility of the applicant for a license pursuant to the provisions of this article and state law, the city council may appoint a liquor committee of the city council. If such liquor committee is established, it shall be organized in such a manner as the city council shall determine by resolution. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.08(1)) 
Cross reference- Boards, committees and commissions, § 2-46 et seq. 
Sec. 3-122. - Investigation of applicant. 
    All applications for a license shall be referred to the liquor committee or the city council for verification and investigation of the facts set forth in the application. The chief of police shall cause to be made such investigation of the information requested in section 3-115 as shall be necessary and shall make a written recommendation and report to the liquor committee or to the city council, as the case may be, which shall include a list of all violations of federal or state law or city ordinance. The liquor committee or city council may order and conduct such additional investigation as it shall deem necessary. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.08(2)) 
Sec. 3-123. - Places ineligible for license. 
(a)  No license shall be granted or renewed for operation on any premises on which taxes, assessments or other financial claims of the city are delinquent and unpaid. 
(b)  No license shall be granted for premises within three hundred (300) feet of any school. In determining this distance, measurement shall be from the nearest door of the premises to be licensed to the nearest door of any school. 
(c)  No license shall be issued for premises owned by a person to whom a license may not be granted under this division, except any owner who is a minor, alien, or a person who has been convicted of a crime other than a violation of M.S.A. §§ 340A.301 through 340A.907. 
(d)  No on-sale license shall be granted to a hotel or motel that does not have a dining area open to the general public with a total minimum floor area of seven hundred (700) square feet, nor to a restaurant with less than one thousand two hundred (1,200) square feet. 
(e)  No license shall be granted for any place which has a common entrance or exit between any two (2) establishments, except that a public concourse or public lobby shall not be construed as a common entrance or exit. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.10; Ord. No. 1052, § 1, 4-20-94) 
Sec. 3-124. - Issuance when premises not ready for occupancy. 
    Where a license is granted for premises where the building is under construction or otherwise not ready for occupancy, the city clerk-treasurer shall not issue the license until notified by the building inspector that a certificate of occupancy has been issued and the building is ready for occupancy. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.08(5)) 
Sec. 3-125. - Area of effect. 
    No license shall be effective beyond the space named in the license for which it was granted, except when the licensee is contracted to dispense liquor pursuant to section 3-175 of the Municipal Code and except when the licensee is issued a permit by the city pursuant to M.S.A. § 340A.404, Subd. 4. A licensee issued a permit pursuant to M.S.A. § 340A.404, Subd. 4 shall pay the permit fee established by the city council and shall comply with Municipal Code sections 3-176; 3-178 and 3-180. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.11(5); Ord. No. 1237, § 1, 5-15-06) 
Sec. 3-126. - Posting. 
    The license shall be posted in a conspicuous place in the licensed establishment at all times. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.11(2)) 
Sec. 3-127. - Transfer. 
    Each license shall be issued to the applicant only. Each license shall be issued only for the premises described in the application. No license may be transferred to another person or to another place without the approval of the city council and without a new application having been filed. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.08(3)) 
Sec. 3-128. - Changes in corporate officers, bylaws, etc.; changes in interest. 
    Changes in the corporate or association officers, corporate charter, articles of incorporation, bylaws or partnership agreement of a licensee shall be submitted to the city clerk within thirty (30) days after such changes are made. Notwithstanding the definition of interest as given in section 3-114(b), in the case of a corporation, the licensee shall notify the city clerk when a person not listed in the application acquires an interest which, together with that of his spouse, parent, brother, sister or child, exceeds five (5) percent, and shall give all information about such person as required by the provisions of section 3-115(b)(4). 
(Code 1978, § 1209.11(17)) 
Sec. 3-129. - Expiration. 
    All licenses shall expire on April 25 of each year. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.07(1)) 
Sec. 3-130. - Renewal-Application. 
    Applications for the renewal of an existing license shall be made at least sixty (60) days prior to the date of the expiration of the license and shall be made in such abbreviated form as the city council may approve. If, in the judgment of the city council, good and sufficient cause is shown by an applicant for his failure to file for a renewal within the time provided, the city council may, if the other provisions of this article are complied with, grant the application. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.05) 
Sec. 3-131. - Same-Statement of sales. 
    At the earliest practicable time after the application is made for a renewal of any on-sale license, and prior to the time that the application is approved, the city council may require the applicant to file with the city clerk-treasurer a statement made by a certified public accountant that shows the total gross sales and the total food sales of the restaurant for the twelve-month period immediately preceding the date for filing renewal applications. A foreign corporation shall file a current certificate of authority. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.05) 
Sec. 3-132. - Refund of license fee-Generally. 
    No part of the fee paid for any license shall be refunded except in accordance with this division. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.07(4)) 
Sec. 3-133. - Same-Termination of sales, sale of business. 
    Upon termination of on-sale liquor sales, a person holding a private on-sale liquor license for a period of more than two (2) consecutive years shall receive a refund of the license fee paid upon forfeiture of the license to the city clerk. A licenseholder who sells the licensed business shall be entitled to a prorated refund of the unused portion of the license fee upon the city's granting of a liquor license to the new business owner. The refund shall be prorated on a monthly basis and each part of a month shall constitute a full month's usage of the license. No refund shall be made to any person who is shown by the records of the county treasurer or county auditor to be delinquent in payments of real estate taxes or delinquent in payments to Willmar Municipal Utilities of the city or delinquent on any other obligations owed to the city or its subdivisions. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.07(8); Ord. No. 876, § 1, 5-21-86) 
Sec. 3-134. - Revocation. 
    The city council may suspend or revoke, pursuant to M.S.A. § 340A.415, any license for the sale of intoxicating liquor, for violation of any provision or condition of this chapter or of any state law or federal law regulating the sale of intoxicating liquor. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.17) 
Sec. 3-135. - Submission of information to liquor control commissioner. 
    The city clerk-treasurer shall, within ten (10) days after the issuance of any license under this division, submit to the liquor control commissioner the full name and address of each person granted a license, the trade name, the effective license date, and the date of expiration of the license. He shall also submit to the liquor control commissioner any change of address, transfer, cancellation or revocation of any license by the council during the license period. 
(Code 1978, § 1209.08(4)) 
Sec. 3-136. - On-sale liquor on Sundays; license, hours of sale. 
(a)  License to be issued. Any restaurant, club, bowling center, or hotel with a seating capacity for at least thirty (30) persons which holds an on-sale intoxicating liquor license shall be issued a license to sell intoxicating liquor on Sunday for consumption on the premises, in conjunction with the sale of food, upon making application for such license and paying the fees herein required. 
(b)  License fee. The annual fee for a Sunday liquor license shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00) and each license shall expire one (1) year from the date of issuance. 
(c)  Hours of sale. Sale of intoxicating liquors shall be allowed between the hours of 10:00 a.m. on Sunday and 1:00 a.m. on Monday. 
(Ord. No. 1033, §§ 1-3, 12-16-92; Ord. No. 1215, § 2, 5-2-05) 
Cross reference- Hours and days of sale of intoxicating liquor, § 3-83. 
Sec. 3-137. - Brewer taproom licenses. 
(a)  Definition. A brewer taproom license shall mean a license authorizing the on-sale of malt liquor produced by a brewer for consumption on the premises of or adjacent to one (1) brewer location owned by the brewer. 
(b)  Issuance of license; fee; conditions of license. Brewer taproom licenses may be issued to the holder of a brewer's license under M.S.A. § 340A.301, subd. 6(c), (i) or (j). Said license may be issued without regard to the limitations contained in sections 3-113 and 3-114 and are subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  The annual license fee for a taproom license, as established in the fee schedule kept on file in the office of the city clerk-treasurer, shall be paid. 
(2)  The investigating fee established in section 3-120 of this Code shall be paid. 
(3)  The license shall be valid on all days of the week consistent with the hours of sale provided in section 3-83 of this Code. 
(4)  A brewer may only hold one (1) brewer taproom license under this section. 
(5)  The only alcoholic beverages sold or consumed on the premises of the taproom will be malt liquor produced by the brewer upon the brewery premises. 
(6)  No taproom shall be located across a public right-of-way such as a street or alley from the brewery location. 
(7)  All other provisions of this article shall be applicable to such licenses and licensees unless inconsistent with the provisions of this section. 
(c)  Nothing in this section shall preclude the holder of a brewer taproom license from also holding a license to operate a restaurant at the taproom location. 
(Ord. No. 1349, § 4, 8-5-13) 
Secs. 3-138-3-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - RESERVED[4]
