(1)  No vehicle of any kind shall be stopped, parked or left standing with its left side to the curb, except as otherwise provided in this section. 
(2)  Unless otherwise modified or determined by the city council as provided in subsection (b) of this section, when any vehicle is to be left standing or parked at the curb on any street, avenue or public place within the city, it shall be left standing or parked within one (1) foot of and parallel to the right-hand curb, but not nearer than three (3) feet from any other vehicles; provided, however, that on all one-way streets, all cars shall be parked facing in the direction of the flow of traffic and parallel to either the right- or left-hand curb, depending on the side of the one-way street upon which the automobile is parked. 
(b)  Modification for designated streets. The city council, in retaining the right to designate the mode, manner and method of parking of automobiles upon the streets of the city, from time to time, in its discretion, may adopt a resolution by the terms of which the manner and method of parking of automobiles may be modified or changed, in particular as to the parallel or angle parking method. In order to adopt such a resolution there shall be an affirmative vote of at least six (6) members of the city council. The resolution shall then be published in the legal newspaper one (1) time, and thereafter, the method, manner and mode of parking of automobiles upon such streets, thoroughfares, avenues or portions thereof as may be designated in the resolution shall be effective. The chief of police shall appropriately mark such streets, or place signs in or near such streets, which shall clearly define the change and indicate the current method of parking of automobiles. 
(Code 1978, §§ 820.01, 820.03, 820.04) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, M.S.A. § 169.35. 
Sec. 15-49. - Double-parking. 
    No vehicle of any kind shall be left standing or double-parked at any time or place, except that vehicles may be double-parked for the purpose of taking on or discharging passengers, only for a sufficient length of time to enable the passengers to enter or to remove themselves from the vehicle, after which the vehicle shall immediately proceed. 
(Code 1978, § 820.07) 
Sec. 15-50. - Parking for more than forty-eight hours prohibited; removal of vehicle. 
    No vehicle, including service trailers, shall be parked or left standing at the curb on any street or avenue or any public place in the city for more than forty-eight (48) hours at any one (1) time. In any case of parking of a vehicle for more than forty-eight (48) hours, any police officer of the city is authorized and empowered to remove the vehicle from the street, avenue or public place where parked and to safely keep the vehicle until the owner or person in charge of the vehicle calls for the vehicle. The owner shall pay to the city, before the automobile is returned to him, such reasonable sum for a towing charge and parking fee as the city council may fix from time to time by motion. The city shall have a lien against the automobile for the amount so determined, which shall be of the same force and effect as a lien against personally in possession of the city. The lien may be foreclosed, and the property taken by the city for the charges, in the manner provided for such procedures under the law of the state relating to foreclosure of motor vehicle liens, M.S.A. § 514.35. For purposes of this section and section 15-55, service trailer shall mean a trailer used for commercial purposes when it is actually being used for commercial purposes and is parked within two hundred (200) feet of the site where the commercial service is being provided. 
(Code 1978, § 820.05; Ord. No. 1223, § 1, 9-6-05) 
Sec. 15-51. - Places where parking prohibited. 
    No person shall park a vehicle or permit it to stand, whether attended or unattended, upon any highway within the city, in any of the following places: 
(1)  On a sidewalk. 
(2)  In front of a public or private driveway. 
(3)  Within an intersection. 
(4)  Within fifteen (15) feet of a fire hydrant. 
(5)  On a crosswalk. 
(6)  Within twenty (20) feet of a crosswalk at an intersection. 
(7)  Within thirty (30) feet of any flashing beacon, stop sign, or traffic-control signal located at the side of a roadway. 
(8)  Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within thirty (30) feet of points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone, unless a different length is indicated by signs or markings. 
(9)  Within fifty (50) feet of the nearest rail of a railroad crossing. 
(10)  Within twenty (20) feet of the driveway entrance to any fire station and, on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station, within seventy-five (75) feet of the entrance, when properly signposted. 
(11)  Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction, when such stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic. 
(12)  On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or curb of a street. 
(13)  Upon any bridge or other elevated structure upon a highway, except as otherwise provided by the council by resolution. 
(14)  At any place where official signs prohibit stopping. 
(Code 1978, § 815.04(b)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, M.S.A. § 169.34. 
Sec. 15-52. - Painting of curbs. 
    The city engineer, by a written designation approved in writing by the mayor and the city council and filed with the city clerk-treasurer, may cause curbs, or portions of curbs, along any street, either within or without the congested district of the city, to be painted with a yellow paint. It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle in the painted zone and alongside thereof at any time; provided, however, that signs, either vertical in type or painted upon the curb portion, may and shall otherwise indicate the type of parking permissible alongside the painted curb area. Restrictions against general parking alongside all yellow-painted portions of curbs bordering the streets and avenues of the city, as now painted and established, shall be deemed to be effective and in compliance with the terms of this section, until changed as provided for in this section. 
(Code 1978, § 815.06) 
Sec. 15-53. - Parking in area designated for street operations. 
(a)  Designation of areas. The city council, by resolution adopted by six (6) affirmative votes of the members thereof, may authorize the chief of police to post or placard such streets, avenues and thoroughfares, or parts or portions thereof, forbidding parking upon the streets during such reasonable hours as the council may determine, for the purpose of permitting removal of snow, or cleaning, sweeping, and flushing of the street. The resolution shall be effective from and after its publication, and the control of the streets and the prohibition against parking at the times as determined in the resolution for such purposes shall be as therein set forth. 
(b)  Posting of areas. The chief of police, in enforcing the terms of such restrictions, shall cause the streets, avenues or thoroughfares, or parts or portions thereof, to be placarded or posted so as to inform the public and the drivers of automobiles concerning the proposed operations upon the streets. The signs or placards shall designate the time of day, days or other periods during which parking shall be prohibited. 
(c)  Towing of vehicles. The chief of police may, under the provisions of this section, cause automobiles parked illegally in the restricted zones in which the street operations are contemplated to be towed to a position of safekeeping. The owner of such automobile, prior to having the automobile returned to him, shall pay such reasonable towing charge as may be charged therefor, or a charge as fixed by motion of the city council. The nonpayment of the towing charge shall give rise to a lien in favor of the city for the amount, with the same force and effect as other towing charge liens described and set forth in this article. The liens shall be enforced and have the same force and effect as set forth for such liens in M.S.A. § 514.35. 
(Code 1978, § 820.05) 
Sec. 15-54. - Parking in area to be used by vehicles engaged in municipal business. 
(a)  Designation of areas. The city council, by a resolution adopted by six (6) affirmative votes of the members thereof, may authorize the chief of police to post or placard such streets, avenues, thoroughfares, alleys, or parts or portions thereof, prohibiting parking thereon during such reasonable hours as the council may determine, as may be necessary for the purpose of permitting vehicles engaged in municipal business to be parked at such locations. The resolution shall be effective from and after its publication. 
(b)  Enforcement of parking restrictions. The chief of police is authorized to enforce such resolution in the same manner as provided in section 15-50. 
(Code 1978, § 820.09) 
Sec. 15-55. - Truck parking. 
    No trucks classified as one-ton vehicles or over, semitrailers or tractors, unattached camping or house trailers, implement trailers, or similar vehicles shall be permitted to park on any public street, thoroughfare, public alley, parking lot or public property for a period longer than two (2) hours, except where such vehicle is parked on a street or thoroughfare on which the adjacent property on both sides of the street or thoroughfare is zoned for light industry (LI) or heavy industry (HI). This restriction shall not apply to vehicles actually engaged in moving household furniture or furnishings, small delivery trucks, service trucks, or service trailers, however, each vehicle or trailer exempted in this section shall be subject to section 15-50. 
(Code 1978, § 820.08; Ord. No. 1223, § 2, 9-6-05) 
Sec. 15-56. - Service parking. 
(a)  Persons eligible for permit; application. There is hereby created a separate category of parking privilege to be known as service parking. Any person engaged in a service trade, such as plumbing, electrical work, telephone repair, maintenance and installation, gas repair, installation and service, and allied and similar service trades, may apply to the chief of police on forms furnished by the city for such service parking privilege. The application shall be accompanied by a fee in an amount as kept on file at the office of the city clerk-treasurer. 
(b)  Issuance of permit. 
(1)  If the application for parking permit is granted by the chief of police, he shall cause a window permit to be issued to the applicant. The permit may be used only for service trucks or service-type vehicles that have in them the service tools of the trade of the applicant. No such permit shall be issued to passenger vehicles owned by an applicant which are not actually used for service work and to carry the service tools of the trade of the applicant. 
(2)  Any questions of issuance of the permit to any applicant shall be resolved by the chief of police, and his decision shall be final concerning the need of the applicant for the permit and other questions of issuance. It is determined by the council that the privilege of parking by issuance of the permit is not a vested right, and that the privilege shall be permitted only for service-type vehicle parking while actually engaged in repair, maintenance and service work associated with the business of the applicant. 
(c)  Additional vehicles. The fee paid by the applicant at the time of issuance of the permit shall apply for only one (1) vehicle. Additional fee payments in the same amount shall be necessary in order to have permits for additional service trucks or service vehicles issued to the applicant. 
(d)  Placement of window permit. Upon being furnished with the permit, the driver of any service truck or vehicle shall place the permit on the upper right-hand side of the windshield. 
(e)  Limitation on parking time. The truck or service vehicle bearing such a permit shall be parked at any place only so long as may be necessary for the occupant thereof to service the appliance that the permittee had been called to service, or otherwise maintain the appliance, at the choice of the permittee. 
(f)  Revocation of permit. Any violation of the conditions under which the permit was issued to the applicant shall be grounds for revocation of the privilege. The revocation of the privilege shall entail the return of the permit to the chief of police. No refund or prorating of any amount paid, in fee or otherwise, shall be made to the applicant under these conditions. The revocation or suspension of a person's privilege shall not preclude the person from reapplying for the issuance or reissuance of the permit. No suspension or revocation of a permit shall be continued for more than one (1) year. The suspension or revocation may be continued for such shorter time as may, in the sole discretion of the chief of police, be proper under the circumstances. 
(Code 1978, § 830.11; Ord. No. 773, § 1, 1-20-82) 
Sec. 15-57. - Parking vehicle for purpose of sale. 
    No vehicle shall be parked on any street for the purpose of displaying it for sale. 
(Code 1978, § 815.04(d)) 
Sec. 15-58. - Parking house trailer for camping purposes. 
    No person shall, for camping purposes, leave or park a house trailer on any street or the right-of-way thereof. 
(Code 1978, § 815.04(c)) 
Sec. 15-59. - Snow emergencies. 
(a)  Declaration of emergency. A period of snow emergency shall be declared by the public works superintendent or the superintendent's designee and shall take effect no earlier than four (4) hours after such declaration. A declaration of snow emergency shall be publicized by news media announcements during such four-hour period, and it shall be the responsibility of the public works superintendent or the superintendent's designee to cause such publication. 
(b)  Parking, towing of vehicles. 
(1)  No person shall park or leave a motor vehicle or trailer on the streets, highways, or alleys within the city during a declared period of snow emergency, or until snow maintenance operations have been fully completed, curb to curb, on the streets, highways, or alleys to be used. 
(2)  No person shall park or leave a motor vehicle or trailer upon any public street, highway, alley or public parking lot within the city within any block or area which has been signed or posted with either permanent or temporary signs restricting, regulating or prohibiting parking in the area or street. Such regulations and signing shall be authorized by the public works superintendent or the superintendent's designee on a temporary basis during a snow emergency period. 
(3)  The public works superintendent or the superintendent's designee shall have the authority to remove or cause to be removed any motor vehicle or trailer parked during a period of declared snow emergency in violation of this section. Such removal shall be to city parking facilities, and shall be at the owner's expense. The cost of the removal shall be assessed in addition to any fines or other penalties imposed by this section. 
(4)  Any police officer who observes any motor vehicle parked during a declared period of snow emergency in violation of the provisions of this section may attach to such vehicle a notice, stating that the vehicle has been parked in violation of this section and instructing the owner or operator of the vehicle to report to the duly authorized representative of the city council in regard to such violation. The owner or operator shall pay such representative a fee of five dollars ($5.00) in full satisfaction of such violation. 
(c)  Placing snow from private property on street, public property. No person shall place or cause to be placed any snow from private property onto any public property, including streets, highways, alleys, boulevards, medians, sidewalks, parking lots, parks or any other public property or part thereof, during a declared snow emergency, unless authorized by the city engineer. 
(Code 1978, § 820.06; Ord. No. 1054, § 3, 4-20-94; Ord. No. 1314, § 5, 3-7-11) 
Cross reference- Removal of snow, ice, etc. from sidewalks, § 13-70. 
Secs. 15-60-15-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - NO PARKING ZONES 

Sec. 15-71. - Generally. 
    Notwithstanding the provisions of any other ordinance relative to the parking of automobiles or vehicles upon the streets, avenues or thoroughfares of the city or upon property owned by the city, it shall be unlawful to park or leave standing any automobile or vehicle next to and adjacent to the curb of any street, thoroughfare or avenue, or upon property owned by the city, which may have been designated as prohibited parking area by virtue of the procedures set forth in this division, and adjacent to which or upon which signs have been erected indicating that no parking is permitted alongside such curbs or on such property. This division is particularly designed to prohibit the parking of vehicles on both sides, or on one (1) side only, of any street, thoroughfare or avenue, or upon property owned by the city, as the conditions of traffic, traffic control and public safety indicate necessary in the judgment of the city council. 
(Code 1978, § 835.01) 
Sec. 15-72. - Designation. 
(a)  The city council, in retaining the right to designate the mode, manner and method of parking of automobiles upon the streets of the city, or in prohibiting the parking thereof along one (1) or both sides of any street, thoroughfare, avenue or property owned by the city, shall proceed in the manner prescribed in this section. 
(b)  When the city engineer recommends to the city council in writing that it is deemed necessary, in order to control traffic and to further the control and movement of traffic, to prohibit parking of vehicles along one (1) or both sides of any street, or upon property owned by the city, the city council, in its discretion, shall, by resolution, propose that parking be prohibited on one (1) or both sides of any street, thoroughfares, avenue, or property owned by the city affected by the recommendation; the resolution shall then be introduced for the consideration of the council. Upon the introduction of the resolution, it shall be voted upon by the city council, referred back to the city engineer for further study, or tabled until a subsequent meeting of the council. A vote by the council on the resolution shall be by roll call, and the resolution shall be deemed adopted upon its securing five (5) affirmative votes. 
(c)  After its adoption, the resolution shall be published in the legal newspaper of the city one (1) time, after which it shall be effective. 
(Code 1978, § 835.02) 
Sec. 15-73. - Erection of signs. 
    The resolution shall provide that the city engineer, through his department, shall erect signs indicating that parking on one (1) or both sides of the street, avenue or thoroughfare, or portions thereof, or on property owned by the city, shall be prohibited. If parking is to be prohibited only during certain hours of the day, the sign shall indicate the hours, as described in the resolution. 
(Code 1978, § 835.03) 
Secs. 15-74-15-85. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - BUSINESS DISTRICT 

Sec. 15-86. - Definition. 
    For purposes of this division, the term "downtown business district" shall mean that area of the city bounded by the following streets: Trott Avenue on the south; Seventh Street Southwest on the west; Highway 12 bypass and Pacific Avenue on the north; and Highway 71 (First Street) on the east. 
(Ord. No. 768, § 6(b), 12-2-81) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 15-87. - Purpose of division. 
    It is the purpose of this division to regulate parking in the downtown business district of the city so as to provide a reasonable amount of free parking to customers and visitors of the downtown area, while at the same time providing a method of dealing with property owners, employees and others who might abuse the hour limitations established for parking. 
(Ord. No. 768, § 1, 12-2-81) 
Sec. 15-88. - Penalties for violation of division. 
    The owner, driver, operator or person in charge of any vehicle parked in any off-street parking area or on-street parking area regulated by this division shall conform to and abide by the parking limitations established for each on-street and off-street parking space. The penalty for parking beyond the time limit established pursuant to section 15-87 and for violating section 15-91 shall be two dollars ($2.00) if the penalty is paid within seventy-two (72) hours of the time of issuance of the notice of violation. All violations not paid within seventy-two (72) hours shall be misdemeanors, punished pursuant to section 1-15. 
(Ord. No. 768, § 5, 12-2-81) 
Sec. 15-89. - Parking time limits-Established. 
    The chief of police shall designate, with the assistance of the city engineer and the approval of the city council, the time limits for parking on each street and parking lot in the downtown business district. The time limit as so determined shall be clearly posted on signs in the parking lots and adjacent to the streets. 
(Ord. No. 768, § 2, 12-2-81) 
Sec. 15-90. - Same-Days and hours of enforcement. 
    The police department shall enforce the time limitations established pursuant to this division on Monday through Saturday, inclusive, from the hours of 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. Enforcement shall also be provided on all holidays, except those holidays during which retail businesses are closed. 
(Ord. No. 768, § 3, 12-2-81) 
Sec. 15-91. - Parking of vehicle within same block. 
(a)  No person shall park his vehicle within the same block on any street for more than the posted time limit during any one (1) time period, between the hours of 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. of days for which enforcement of the parking time limitation is required by section 15-90. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, the term "block" shall mean the on-street parking area located between each set of intersections, measuring approximately three hundred (300) to three hundred fifty (350) feet in distance, which is commonly known as one (1) side of a city block. 
(Ord. No. 768, §§ 4, 6(a), 12-2-81) 
Secs. 15-92-15-115. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CONGESTED DISTRICT 

Sec. 15-116. - District established. 
    There is hereby established a district, to be known as the congested district, within which the rules set forth in this article shall be in force. The congested district shall include, in their entirety, the following parts of the following named streets, thoroughfares and avenues: 
(1)  First, Second, Third, Fourth, Fifth and Sixth Streets West, between the north side of Pacific Avenue and the south side of Becker Avenue. 
(2)  Pacific, Benson, Litchfield and Becker Avenues, between the east side of First Street and the west side of Sixth Street West. 
(3)  The north side of Gorton Avenue, between Ninth Street and Tenth Street West. 
(Code 1978, § 815.05(a)) 
Sec. 15-117. - U-turns. 
    No person driving a vehicle within the city shall make a U-turn on any street or intersection at any place within the congested district. 
(Code 1978, § 815.03) 
Sec. 15-118. - No right turn, no left turn intersections. 
    The city engineer, by a written designation approved in writing by the mayor and filed with the city clerk-treasurer, may, whenever necessary to preserve a free flow of traffic or to prevent accidents, designate any intersection within the congested district as one where the turning of a vehicle to the left or to the right, or both, is to be restricted or forbidden, and shall mark by appropriate signs any intersection so designated. No intersection on a trunk highway shall be so designated until the consent of the commissioner of highways of the state to such designation is obtained. No person shall turn a vehicle at any such intersection contrary to the directions of such signs. 
(Code 1978, § 815.05(e)) 
Sec. 15-119. - Loading zones. 
(a)  Generally. The city engineer, by a written designation approved in writing by the mayor and filed with the city clerk-treasurer, may establish any portion of any street in the congested district as a loading zone, and shall mark by appropriate signs the zone so established. Such zones shall be located at places most convenient for the use of the public and with regard to traffic conditions in the street. No person, shall, between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. of any weekday, park any vehicle in any loading zone, except for the purpose of receiving or discharging passengers or freight, and then only for a period no longer than is necessary for the discharge or receipt of such passengers or freight. 
(b)  Bus loading zones. In any such zone where buses load or unload passengers, no person shall, between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. on any day, including Sundays, park any vehicle in any such loading zone except for the purpose of receiving or discharging passengers, and then only for such period of time as may be necessary. 
(Code 1978, § 815.05(d)) 
Sec. 15-120. - Limited parking zones. 
    The city engineer, by a written designation approved in writing by the mayor, and filed with the city clerk-treasurer, may designate certain streets or certain portions of streets within the congested district as ten-minute, twenty-minute, thirty-minute, forty-five-minute, one-hour or two-hour limited parking zones, and shall mark by appropriate signs any zones so designated. Such zones may be established in the congested district wherever necessary for the convenience of the public or to minimize traffic hazards and to preserve the free flow of traffic. No person shall park any vehicle in any limited parking zone so established and marked, between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. on Monday through Friday inclusive of any week, or between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. on any Saturday, for a longer period of time than is specified on the signs marking such zones. 
(Code 1978, § 815.05(c)) 
Sec. 15-121. - No truck parking zones. 
    The city engineer, by a written designation approved in writing by the mayor and by the city council and filed with the city clerk-treasurer, may establish "no truck parking" zones at any place in the congested district, and shall mark by appropriate signs any zone so established. Such zones may be established in the congested district where heavy traffic by commercial vehicles, or other traffic congestion, makes parking by commercial vehicles a hazard to the safety of vehicles or pedestrians. No person shall park a commercial vehicle of more than one-ton capacity between 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. on any weekday upon any street in any no truck parking zone, except that parking of such vehicles for a period of not more than thirty (30) minutes shall be permitted in such zones for the purpose of having access to abutting property when such access cannot conveniently be secured from an alley or from another street where truck parking is not so restricted. 
(Code 1978, § 815.05(b)) 
Secs. 15-122-15-135. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - TRUCK ROUTES 

Sec. 15-136. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Deviating truck means a truck which leaves and departs from a street designated to be used by truck traffic. 
    Truck means: 
(1)  Any vehicle designed or operated for the transportation of property, the total marked gross vehicle weight of which, loaded or unloaded, exceeds fifteen thousand (15,000) pounds; or 
(2)  Any vehicle which is registered for and pays a tax or vehicle license fee based on a gross vehicle weight of more than fifteen thousand (15,000) pounds. 
    Truck route means any street, as designated in this article, over and along which trucks within the city must operate. 
(Code 1978, § 880.01; Ord. No. 852, § 1, 6-19-85) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 15-137. - Authority to require weighing of trucks. 
    Any police officer shall have the authority to require any person driving or in control of any truck not proceeding over a truck route or street upon which truck traffic is permitted to proceed to any public or private scale available, for the purpose of weighing the truck and determining whether this article has been complied with. 
(Code 1978, § 880.04(c)) 
Sec. 15-138. - Liability of owner for violations. 
    In addition to the driver or operator, the owner of any truck that is being operated with the owner's permission and consent shall be liable for any violation of the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1978, § 880.04(d)) 
Sec. 15-139. - Routes designated. 
    The following streets, highways and state aid roads are hereby established or designated within the city as truck routes: 
(a)  Business 71 and 23. 
(b)  19th Avenue SE and SW. 
(c)  Lakeland Drive SE and NE. 
(d)  Willmar Avenue SE. 
(e)  Civic Center Drive. 
(f)  CSAH #24. 
(g)  CSAH #41 north of CSAH #24. 
(h)  CSAH #5. 
(i)  CSAH #47. 
(j)  22nd Street SW from Willmar Avenue to 19th Avenue SW. 
(k)  Willmar Avenue SW from 22nd Street SW to Minnesota Highway #40. 
(l)  High Avenue NE from Lakeland Drive NE to 10th Street NE. 
(m)  10th Street NE. 
(n)  All U.S. and State Trunk Highways. 
(Code 1978, § 880.03; Ord. No. 1247, § 1, 11-20-06) 
Sec. 15-140. - Maps; sign posting. 
(a)  The city engineer shall keep and maintain accurate maps setting out the truck routes or streets upon which truck traffic is permitted. Such maps shall be available to the public. 
(b)  The city engineer shall cause all truck routes and streets upon which truck traffic is permitted to be clearly signposted. 
(Code 1978, § 880.04(a), (b)) 
Sec. 15-141. - Trucks restricted to designated routes; exceptions. 
    All trucks operating within the city shall be operated only over and along the truck routes established in section 15-139, except that this article shall not prohibit: 
(1)  The operation of trucks upon any street, where necessary to the conduct of business, only to a destination point, provided that streets upon which such traffic is permitted are used until reaching the intersection nearest the destination point. This exemption does not include the parking or driving of trucks from or to the owner's or operator's home in a residential-zoned area. 
(2)  The operation of emergency vehicles upon any street in the city. 
(3)  The operation of trucks owned or operated by the state, the county, the city, public utilities, or any contractor or materials man, while engaged in the repair, maintenance or construction of streets, street improvements or street utilities within the city. 
(4)  The operation of trucks upon any officially established detour in any case where such truck could be lawfully operated on the street for which such detour is established. 
(Code 1978, § 880.02; Ord. No. 830, § 1, 7-18-84) 
Secs. 15-142-15-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - SNOWMOBILES AND ATV's[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Use and driving of snowmobiles and certain other vehicles in parks restricted, § 11-78. 
State Law reference- Recreational vehicles, M.S.A. § 84.81 et seq. 

Sec. 15-161. - Intent of article. 
    It is the intent of this article to supplement the laws of the state relating to the operation of certain motor vehicles commonly called snowmobiles and ATV's. This article is not intended to allow what the state statutes prohibit, nor to prohibit what the state statutes expressly allow, except as specifically provided in this article. 
(Code 1978, § 807.01; Ord. No. 905, § 1, 6-3-87) 
Sec. 15-162. - Definition. 
    For purposes of this article, an ATV is a vehicle as defined by M.S.A. § 84.92. 
(Ord. No. 905, § 1, 6-3-87) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 15-163. - Operation prohibited in certain areas. 
    It is unlawful for any person within the city limits to operate a snowmobile or ATV: 
(1)  On private property of another, without permission of the owner of the property. 
(2)  On sidewalks and publicly owned land, including schools, park property, recreation areas and playgrounds, unless the area has been specifically designated by the city for such use. 
(Code 1978, § 807.02(a), (b); Ord. No. 905, § 1, 6-3-87; Ord. No. 991, § 1, 11-21-90) 
Sec. 15-164. - Time of operation. 
    No snowmobile or ATV shall be operated within the city between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., unless the operator is returning to his place of abode after operating such snowmobile or ATV outside of the city limits. 
(Code 1978, § 807.04; Ord. No. 905, § 1, 6-3-87) 
Sec. 15-165. - Creation of unnecessary noise. 
    It is unlawful for any person within the city limits to operate a snowmobile or ATV in a manner so as to create a loud, unnecessary or unusual noise which disturbs, annoys or interferes with the peace and quiet of other persons. 
(Code 1978, § 807.02(c); Ord. No. 905, § 1, 6-3-87) 
Cross reference- Noise, § 9-86 et seq. 
Sec. 15-166. - Safety regulations. 
(a)  No person shall operate or haul any snowmobile or ATV carelessly or heedlessly in disregard of the rights or the safety of others, or in a manner so as to endanger or be likely to endanger any person or property. 
(b)  No person shall operate any snowmobile or ATV in excess of twenty (20) miles per hour, except at a snowmobile or ATV race or competition that has been approved by the city council. 
(c)  Snowmobiles and ATV's operated on city streets must travel in single file. 
(d)  Every operator of a snowmobile or ATV shall yield the right-of-way at any intersection in the city to any pedestrian or to any motor vehicle which is approaching the intersection in such a manner as to constitute an immediate hazard. In all events, the operator of every snowmobile or ATV shall stop or reduce his speed at intersections so as to avoid colliding with any person or motor vehicle lawfully using the streets or highways. 
(Code 1978, §§ 807.03, 807.05; Ord. No. 905, § 1, 6-3-87; Ord. No. 1016, § 1, 1-8-92) 
Sec. 15-167. - Operation by minors on city streets. 
(a)  No person under the age of twelve (12) years shall operate a snowmobile or ATV on a public street or thoroughfare within the city. 
(b)  No person between the ages of twelve (12) years and eighteen (18) years shall operate a snowmobile or ATV on a public street or thoroughfare or unless he shall have in his immediate possession a valid snowmobile safety certificate issued by the department of natural resources of the state. 
(Code 1978, § 807.06; Ord. No. 905, § 1, 6-3-87) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, M.S.A. § 84.9256. 
Secs. 15-168-15-180. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - PARADES AND PROCESSIONS[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Consumption of intoxicating liquor in unlicensed public places restricted, § 3-3; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 13. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 15-181. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the parade ordinance of the city. 
(Code 1978, § 875.01) 
Sec. 15-182. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Parade means any parade, march, ceremony, show, exhibition, pageant or procession of any kind, or rally or demonstration, or any similar display, in or upon any street, park or other outdoor place owned or under the control of the city. 
    Parade permit means a permit as required by this article. 
(Code 1978, § 875.02(3), (4)) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 15-183. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Any person violating the provisions of any section of this article shall, upon conviction, be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1978, § 875.15(4)) 
Sec. 15-184. - Injunctive relief. 
    Nothing in this article providing for the regulation or licensing of parades, or setting forth penalties for violation of this article, shall waive the right of or otherwise preclude the city or any of its residents from seeking or obtaining injunctive relief in a court of general jurisdiction for the purpose of prohibiting or regulating any proposed or licensed parade. 
(Code 1978, § 875.16) 
Sec. 15-185. - Conduct of parade. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to stage, present or conduct, or attempt to stage, present or conduct a parade, without first having obtained a permit therefor as provided in this article, or to conduct a parade which otherwise violates any of the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1978, § 875.15(1)) 
Sec. 15-186. - Compliance with conditions of permit, applicable laws. 
(a)  A permittee under this article shall comply with all permit directions and conditions and with applicable laws and ordinances. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to comply with all directions and conditions of a parade permit. 
(Code 1978, §§ 875.11, 875.15(3)) 
Sec. 15-187. - Participating in parade for which permit has not been granted. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to participate in a parade on the city streets for which a permit has not been granted. 
(Code 1978, § 875.15(2)) 
Sec. 15-188. - Interfering with parade. 
    No person shall unreasonably hamper, obstruct, impede, or interfere with any parade or parade assembly, or with any person, vehicle or animal participating or used in a parade. 
(Code 1978, § 875.12(1)) 
Sec. 15-189. - Driving through parade. 
    No driver of any vehicle shall drive between the vehicles or persons constituting a parade when such vehicles or persons are in motion and are conspicuously designated as a parade. 
(Code 1978, § 875.12(2)) 
Sec. 15-190. - Parking on parade route. 
    The chief of police shall have the authority, when reasonably necessary, to prohibit or restrict the parking of vehicles along a highway or part thereof constituting a part of the route of a parade. The chief of police shall post signs to such effect, and it shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave unattended any vehicle in violation of such signs. No person shall be liable for a violation of this section if the person's vehicle is parked on an unposted street. 
(Code 1978, § 875.12(3)) 
Secs. 15-191-15-205. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 15-206. - Required; exceptions. 
(a)  No person shall engage in, participate in, aid, form or start any parade, unless a parade permit has been obtained from the chief of police. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to: 
(1)  Funeral processions. 
(2)  Lawful picketing or other orderly processions on the sidewalks that do not violate any other state or city laws. 
(3)  A government agency acting within the scope of its functions. 
(Code 1978, § 875.03) 
Sec. 15-207. - Application. 
(a)  Filing. 
(1)  A person seeking the issuance of a parade permit shall file an application with the chief of police on forms provided by the chief of police. 
(2)  An application for a parade permit shall be filed with the chief of police not less than five (5) days before the date on which it is proposed to conduct the parade. 
(3)  The application shall be signed by the applicant and notarized. 
(b)  Contents. The application for a parade permit shall set forth the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the person seeking to conduct such parade. 
(2)  If the parade is proposed to be conducted for, on behalf of, or by an organization, the name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization, and of the authorized and responsible heads of such organization. 
(3)  The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be the parade chairman and who will be responsible for its conduct. 
(4)  The date when the parade is to be conducted. 
(5)  The route to be traveled, the starting point and the termination point. 
(6)  The approximate number of persons, animals and vehicles which will constitute such parade, the type of animals, and a description of the vehicles. 
(7)  The hours when such parade will start and terminate. 
(8)  A statement as to whether the parade will occupy all or only a portion of the width of the streets proposed to be traversed. 
(9)  The location, by streets, of any assembly areas for such parade. 
(10)  The time at which units of the parade will begin to assemble at any such assembly areas. 
(11)  The purpose of the parade. 
(12)  Any additional information which the chief of police shall find reasonably necessary to a fair determination as to whether a permit should be issued. 
(c)  Authorization when parade is to be held by person other than applicant. If the parade is designed to be held by, on behalf of or for any person other than the applicant, the applicant for such permit shall file with the chief of police a communication in writing from the person proposing to hold the parade, authorizing the applicant to apply for the permit on his behalf. 
(d)  Late applications. The chief of police, where good cause is shown therefor, shall have the authority to consider any application under this division which is filed less than five (5) days before the date such parade is proposed to be conducted. 
(e)  Fee. A fee in an amount as kept on file in the office of the city clerk-treasurer, to cover the expenses incident to processing, shall be paid by the person applying for the permit at the time of the filing of the application. 
(Code 1978, § 875.04) 
Sec. 15-208. - Indemnification of city. 
    The applicant for a parade permit, and any other person on whose behalf the application is made, by filing such application, do represent, stipulate, contract and agree that they will jointly and severally indemnify and hold the city harmless against liability for any and all claims for damage to property resulting from the issuance of the permit or the conduct of the parade or its participants. 
(Code 1978, § 875.14(1)) 
Sec. 15-209. - Insurance. 
(a)  No parade permit shall be issued unless the applicant therefor shall obtain a comprehensive general liability insurance policy, issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in the state, with coverage that includes the assembly area, the parade route, the disbanding area of the parade, and any other area used by the participants of the parade. The city shall be named as an additional insured on the policy. The policy limits of the insurance shall not be less than the following: 
(1)  For property damage fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for each occurrence. 
(2)  For bodily injury or death, fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for each person and three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for each occurrence. 
(b)  At the time of the application for the parade permit, satisfactory proof that the required insurance has been obtained must be presented to the chief of police. The requirement for satisfactory proof may be complied with either by depositing the insurance policy itself to the chief of police or by furnishing a certificate of insurance meeting the following specifications: 
(1)  The insurance policies issued should be listed and, for each policy, the type of insurance, policy number, expiration date and limits of liability should be shown. 
(2)  The certificate should designate the city as certificate holder and as an additional insured, and should contain a statement to the effect that the policies listed are in force, and that in the event of cancellation or any material change in a policy affecting the certificate holder, at least ten (10) days' prior written notice will be given to the certificate holder. 
(3)  Below the schedule of insurance in force, the certificate should include a statement substantially as follows: 
"The comprehensive general liability policy listed above includes coverage of designated premises and coverage for contractual liability in compliance with the provisions of section 15-181 et seq. of the Municipal Code of the City of Willmar, for a parade to be held on ________, 19___." 
(4)  The certificate should be signed by an authorized agent of the issuing company and should have attached a copy of a valid power of attorney. 
(c)  The requirements of subsections (a) and (b) of this section shall not be applicable to parades composed of pedestrians only, which do not include any vehicles or animals. If motor vehicles are to be included, evidence of public liability insurance, with the same limits on such vehicles, may be accepted in lieu of the insurance required in subsections (a) and (b) of this section. 
(Code 1978, § 875.14(2)) 
Sec. 15-210. - Standards for issuance. 
    The chief of police shall issue a permit as provided for under this article when, from a consideration of the application and from such other information as may otherwise be obtained, he finds that: 
(1)  The conduct of the parade will not substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of other traffic contiguous to its route. 
(2)  The conduct of the parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of police officers of the city to properly police the line of movement and the areas contiguous thereto as to prevent normal police protection to the city. 
(3)  The conduct of such parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of ambulances as to prevent normal ambulance service to portions of the city other than that to be occupied by the proposed line of march and areas contiguous thereto. 
(4)  The concentration of persons, animals and vehicles at assembly points of the parade will not unduly interfere with proper fire and police protection of or ambulance service to areas contiguous to such assembly areas. 
(5)  The conduct of such parade will not interfere with the movement of firefighting equipment en route to a fire. 
(6)  The conduct of the parade is not reasonably likely to cause injury to persons or property, to provoke disorderly conduct, or create a disturbance. 
(7)  The parade is scheduled to move from its point of origin to its point of termination expeditiously and without unreasonable delays en route. 
(8)  The parade is not to be held for the sole purpose of advertising any product, goods or event, and is not designed to be held purely for private profit; provided, however, the prohibition against advertising any product, goods or event shall not apply to signs identifying organizations or sponsors furnishing or sponsoring floats or transportation for the parade. 
(Code 1978, § 875.05) 
Sec. 15-211. - Granting; denial. 
    The chief of police shall act upon the application for a parade permit within three (3) days after the filing thereof. If the chief of police disapproves the application, he shall mail to the applicant by registered mail, or have served upon the applicant, within two (2) days after the date upon which the application was filed, a notice of his action, stating the reasons for his denial of the permit. 
(Code 1978, § 875.06) 
Sec. 15-212. - Alternative permit. 
    The chief of police, in denying an application for a parade permit, shall be empowered to authorize the conduct of the parade on a date, at a time, or over route different from that named by the applicant. An applicant desiring to accept an alternative permit shall, within three (3) days after notice of the action of the chief of police, file a written notice of acceptance with the chief of police. An alternate parade permit shall conform to the requirements of and shall have the effect of a parade permit under this article. 
(Code 1978, § 875.08) 
Sec. 15-213. - Contents of permit. 
    Each parade permit shall state the following information: 
(1)  The date of the parade. 
(2)  The starting time and termination time of the parade. 
(3)  The portions of the streets to be traversed that may be occupied by the parade. 
(4)  The number of persons, animals and motor vehicles that will be in the parade. 
(5)  Such other information as the chief of police shall find necessary to the enforcement of this article. 
(Code 1978, § 875.10) 
Sec. 15-214. - Copies of permit to be sent to city officials. 
    Immediately upon the issuance of a parade permit, the chief of police shall send a copy thereof to the following: 
(1)  The mayor. 
(2)  The city clerk-treasurer. 
(3)  The city attorney. 
(4)  The city engineer. 
(5)  The fire chief. 
(6)  The county attorney. 
(7)  The county sheriff. 
(Code 1978, § 875.09) 
Sec. 15-215. - Appeal from denial. 
    Any person aggrieved by the denial of a parade permit shall have the right to appeal the denial of the permit to the city council. The appeal shall be taken within three (3) days after receipt of the notice of denial. The city council shall act upon the appeal within fourteen (14) days after receipt. 
(Code 1978, § 875.07) 
Sec. 15-216. - Person heading parade to carry permit during parade. 
    The parade chairman or other person heading or leading such activity shall carry the parade permit upon his person during the conduct of the parade. 
(Code 1978, § 875.11(1)) 
Sec. 15-217. - Revocation. 
    The chief of police shall have the authority to revoke a parade permit upon violation of section 15-209 or 15-210. 
(Code 1978, § 875.13) 
Secs. 15-218-15-230. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - EXCESSIVE VEHICLE NOISE[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 1246, §§ 1-6, 8, adopted November 20, 2006, did not specifically amend the Code. Therefore, such ordinance has been added as §§ 15-231-15-237, at the editor's discretion. 
Cross reference- Noise, § 9-86 et seq. 

Sec. 15-231. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this article, the following phrases are defined as follows: 
    "Abnormal or excessive noise" shall mean (a) distinct and loudly audible noise that unreasonably annoys, disturbs, injures or endangers the comfort and repose of any person or precludes their enjoyment of property or affects their property's value, (b) noise in excess of that permitted by M.S.A. §§ 169.69, as it may be amended from time to time, which requires every motor vehicle to be equipped with a muffler in good working order, or (c) noise in excess of that permitted by M.S.A. § 169.693 and Minnesota Rules Parts 7030.1000 through 7030.1050, as this statute and these rules may be amended from time to time, which establish motor vehicle noise standards. 
    "Engine retarding brake" shall mean a Dynamic Brake, Jake Brake, Jacobs Brake, C-Brake, Paccar Brake, transmission brake or other similar engine retarding brake system which alters the normal compression of the engine and subsequently releases that compression. 
(Ord. No. 1246, § 1, 11-20-06) 
Sec. 15-232. - Muffler required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge the exhaust or permit the discharge of the exhaust from any motor vehicle except through a muffler that effectively prevents abnormal or excessive noise and complies with all applicable state laws and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 1246, § 2, 11-20-06) 
Sec. 15-233. - Engine retarding brakes restricted. 
    It shall be unlawful for the operator of any truck to intentionally use an engine retarding brake on any public highway, street, parking lot or alley within the city which causes abnormal or excessive noise from the engine because of an illegally modified or defective exhaust system, except in an emergency. 
(Ord. No. 1246, § 3, 11-20-06) 
Sec. 15-234. - Vehicles exempted. 
    Authorized emergency vehicles as defined in M.S.A. § 169.01, Subd. 5, shall be exempt from the provisions of this ordinance and vehicles participating in races and events approved by the city council or participating at city approved race tracks shall also be exempt. 
(Ord. No. 1246, § 4, 11-20-06) 
Sec. 15-235. - Statutes and Administrative Rules adopted. 
    M.S.A. §§ 169.69 and 169.693 (motor vehicle noise limits) and Minnesota Rules Parts 7030.1000 through 7030.1050, as these statutes and rules may be amended from time to time, are hereby adopted by reference. 
(Ord. No. 1246, § 5, 11-20-06) 
Sec. 15-236. - Signs required. 
    Signs stating "VEHICLE NOISE LAWS ENFORCED" shall be installed at locations deemed appropriate by the city council to advise motorists of the prohibitions contained in this article, except that no sign stating "VEHICLE NOISE LAWS ENFORCED" shall be installed on a state highway without a permit from the Minnesota Department of Transportation. 
(Ord. No. 1246, § 6, 11-20-06) 
Sec. 15-237. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person, firm or corporation who violates any provision of this article shall, upon conviction, be guilty of a petty misdemeanor and punished by a fine of not more than three hundred dollars ($300.00). 
(Ord. No. 1246, § 8, 11-20-06) 
Chapter 16 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Public utilities, § 4.02(9); municipal utilities commission, § 4.05; financial procedures, art. V. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-1. - Installation of toilets; connection to water, sewer mains. 
(a)  Required. Every owner of any real property which has a dwelling house or a building used for business purposes situated thereon, which real property abuts upon any public street or alley along which water and sewer mains have been constructed, shall install a toilet in the dwelling or building used for business purposes and shall make connection with the water and sewer mains in the street or alley adjacent thereto. 
(b)  Time for compliance; service of notice. It shall be unlawful for the owner of any real property situated as described in subsection (a) of this section to fail or neglect to install such toilet or to make such connection with the water and sewer mains within thirty (30) days after written notice is served upon such owner to install such toilet and to make such connection. The notice shall be served by order of the city council upon action taken by the council by a majority vote of all of the members thereof. The written notice served upon the owner shall be prepared by the city clerk-treasurer, and shall be served upon the owner personally. 
(c)  Failure to connect; unconnected premises declared nuisance. 
(1)  Failure to comply with subsection (a) of this section is declared to be a public nuisance affecting health from and after the expiration of the period of thirty (30) days after the service of the notice described in subsection (b) of this section. The failure or neglect of the owner to install such toilet and to make connection with the sewer and water mains within the period prescribed in the notice shall constitute a misdemeanor. 
(2)  A new notice may be served upon the owner after the expiration of the thirty-day period mentioned in subsection (b) of this section. If the new notice is not complied with, such failure and neglect on the part of the owner shall constitute a new violation of this section, and the owner shall be again guilty of a misdemeanor. Each and every failure to comply with any such notice shall be a separate offense under this section. 
(Code 1978, §§ 130.01-130.03, 1420.01, 1420.02) 
Sec. 16-2. - Certain outside toilets, cesspools, septic tanks deemed nuisance; removal. 
    When a toilet connected with the city water and sewer system has been installed in any residence or business building on any parcel of land, any outside toilet, cesspool, or septic tank on that parcel is declared to be a nuisance. Such outside toilet, cesspool or septic tank shall be removed by the owner or occupant within ten (10) days after the connection to the water and sewer system has been made. 
(Code 1978, § 1420.03) 
Sec. 16-3. - Damaging utility poles. 
    No person shall in any manner mar, disfigure, injure or cut any telephone pole, telegraph pole, electric light pole, or guy stub of the city. 
(Code 1978, § 605.02) 
Secs. 16-4-16-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WATER 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 16-26-16-35. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - WATER SHORTAGES 

Sec. 16-36. - Establishment and publication of water use restrictions. 
(a)  Whenever the municipal utilities commission of the city determines, by resolution, that a shortage exists in the city water supply, the municipal utilities commission shall, by such resolution, establish a limit on the times and hours during which city water may be used for sprinkling, irrigation, noncommercial carwashing, air conditioning, or such other specified uses as shall be enumerated in the resolution. 
(b)  The resolution establishing restrictions provided for in subsection (a) of this section shall be published twice, on consecutive days, in the legal newspaper of the city. 
(Ord. No. 935, §§ 1, 2, 9-21-88) 
Sec. 16-37. - Penalties for violation of resolution restricting use. 
(a)  No person shall use or permit water to be used in violation of the resolution adopted by the municipal utilities commission pursuant to this division. Any person that does so violate the resolution shall be charged one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each day a violation occurs, and such charge shall be added to the next utility bill submitted to that person. 
(b)  Any person who continues to violate the resolution adopted by the municipal utilities commission shall have his water service disconnected until such time as the water shortage is alleviated. 
(Ord. No. 935, §§ 3, 4, 9-21-88) 
Secs. 16-38-16-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SANITARY SEWER SYSTEM 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 16-56. - Violation of article. 
    It is unlawful for any user to violate any provision of this article or fail to comply with the provisions of this article or fail to make connection as provided in this article. 
(Code 1978, § 705.05; Ord. No. 1284, § 2, 2-2-09) 
Sec. 16-57. - Inspections. 
    It shall be the duty of the director of public works, wastewater treatment plant superintendent or their respective designee to make inspections of locations subject to the provisions of this article, and to take all necessary steps to enforce the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1978, § 715.3; Ord. No. 1284, § 3, 2-2-09) 
Sec. 16-58. - Discharging stormwater, roof water or ground water to sanitary sewer. 
    No owner of any real property within the city, or his agents, employees or servants, shall run or discharge or cause to be run or discharged any stormwater, roof water or foundation drainage into any sanitary sewer, or have any property connected to a sanitary sewer by a pipe, connection or sewer which carries either stormwater, roof water or foundation drainage from such building or property into such sanitary sewer. 
(Code 1978, § 705.01; Ord. No. 1284, § 4, 2-2-09) 
Sec. 16-59. - Grease traps and interceptors for certain businesses. 
    Every user who handles food, including restaurants, hotels and meat markets, and every user who maintains a filling station or a place for washing cars, a place for dressing poultry, or a slaughtering establishment shall equip the establishment with and maintain a grease trap and grease interceptors so as to prevent all such wastes mentioned in this article from entering any sewer, either sanitary or storm. All such wastes shall be removed with such frequency that no such refuse ever enters any such sewer, and such refuse shall be removed from the premises and disposed of in a sanitary manner. 
(Code 1978, § 715.02; Ord. No. 1284, § 5, 2-2-09) 
Sec. 16-60. - Control by authorized representative. 
    The city administrator shall be the authorized representative under this article, who shall have control and general supervision of all public sewers and service connections in the city and shall be responsible for administering this article to ensure that a proper and efficient public sewer is maintained. The authorized representative may delegate responsibilities to designated representatives, any of whom may be referred to as "the representative." 
(Ord. No. 1396, § 1, 12-19-16) 
Secs. 16-61-16-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONNECTIONS 

Sec. 16-71. - Permit. 
(a)  Required. 
(1)  No user shall tap or connect, either directly or indirectly, with any sewer within the limits of the city, without first having obtained permission therefor from the director of public works and had a permit issued therefor under the hand and seal of the city clerk-treasurer; nor shall any user so tap or connect, either directly or indirectly, without first having paid to the city clerk-treasurer the fee or charge provided for in this section. 
(2)  No user having a connection with any sewer in the city from any lot or from any building of any kind shall connect or permit any other user to connect therewith from any other lot or building whatsoever owned or controlled by such other user, without first having obtained permission from the director of public works and a permit from the city clerk-treasurer as provided in this section, or unless such other user has obtained permission from the director of public works and a permit from the city clerk-treasurer as provided in this section. 
(3)  Connections to the city's sewer system, including extensions shall be designed such that all facilities conform to: 
 Minnesota Plumbing Code. 
 City Engineers of Minnesota (CEAM) Current Sanitary Sewer Standard Specifications. 
(b)  Fee. 
(1)  The fee for tapping or connecting, either directly or indirectly, with any sewer within the limits of the city, which fee is to be determined as set forth in this section, shall be paid in advance to the city clerk-treasurer before the issuance of a permit for such tapping or connection. 
(2)  Such fee for tapping shall not be less than a specified minimum amount as kept on file at the office of the city clerk-treasurer. In any application for a sewer tapping permit, if the director of public works certifies in writing to the city council that the cost of the sewer line running past the premises in question exceeds the minimum sum, then the council shall, by motion, determine the proper tapping fee to be paid by the applicant for the permit in that instance, so that the tapping fee reimburses the proper fund of the city for the actual cost of the sewer line making possible the furnishing of sewer service to the applicant's premises. 
(3)  The fee or charge shall be paid for each and every such tapping or connection from each and every lot and from each and every house, dwelling, residence, outhouse, barn, store, hotel or building, of whatsoever name or nature, and whether the connection is made directly or indirectly, or through or by means of the connection with the sewer of any other lot or house, dwelling, residence, outhouse, barn, store, hotel or other building; provided, however, that when more than one (1) building, other than dwellings or residences, is situated on any lot, piece or parcel of land, a connection from such buildings shall be considered as only one (1) connection, and only one (1) minimum charge, or such additional amount as may be determined under the provisions of this section, shall be made therefor. 
(4)  The provisions of this section as to the payment of a fee or charge shall not apply to any lot, piece or parcel of land or to any building of any kind that is situated on any lot, piece or parcel of land that has previously been assessed for benefits under the provisions of the charter of the city for the building and construction of the sewer which is sought to be tapped or connected with, unless the assessment has not been paid. 
(5)  In fixing any sewer tapping charge exceeding the minimum amount, the city council may consider, in its discretion, the amount which may have been contributed by the present owner and applicant or prior owners of the property in the construction of a private sewer line which has subsequently become the property of the city by attachment to the city sewer system. 
(6)  All tapping fees collected under this section shall be paid into the sewer service fund of the city. 
(7)  Connection fee pays for the cost of capacity for new interceptor sewers 21 inches in diameter and larger. The connection fee cost includes all the interceptors 21 inches in diameter. The connection fee is $2,435.00 per connection and may be increased on a yearly basis to correct for inflation. 
(Code 1978, §§ 140.01-140.03, 140.05, 140.06; Ord. No. 1284, § 6, 2-2-09) 
Sec. 16-72. - Connection to storm sewer required for certain buildings. 
(a)  Premises where required. It is the duty of every owner of real property which abuts upon any public street or alley along which a storm sewer is constructed or maintained, upon which there is a building used for business purposes where foundation drainage, stormwater or roof water collects, to make connection with the storm sewer in the street or alley adjacent thereto and to lead such stormwater and roof water to the storm sewer by means of a pipe or conduit. 
(b)  Notice to connect. It shall be unlawful for the owner of any real property so situated to fail or neglect to make connection with the storm sewer within thirty (30) days after written notice is served upon such owner to make such connection. The notice shall be served by order of the city council upon action taken by the council by majority vote of all the members thereof. A written notice so to be served on an owner shall be prepared by the city clerk-treasurer and shall be served upon the owner personally. 
(c)  Failure to connect. Failure or neglect of the owner to make connection with the storm sewer within the period described in the notice will constitute a misdemeanor. A new notice may be served upon the owner after the expiration of the thirty-day period and, if not complied with, such failure and neglect on the part of the owner shall constitute a new and separate violation of this section and the owner shall again be guilty of a misdemeanor. Each and every failure to comply with any such notice shall be a separate offense under this section. 
(Code 1978, §§ 705.02-705.04; Ord. No. 1284, § 7, 2-2-09) 
Sec. 16-73. - Specifications for pipes. 
    Comply with the CEAM Sanitary Sewer System Design Standards which may be obtained from the director of public works. 
(Code 1978, § 140.04; Ord. No. 1284, § 8, 2-2-09) 
Secs. 16-74-16-85. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SEWER USE REGULATIONS 

Sec. 16-86. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Act means the Federal Water Pollution Control Act (33 U.S.C. § 1251 et seq.), as amended by the Federal Water Pollution Control Act Amendments of 1972 (Public Law 92-500 and Public Law 93-243), or as modified by M.S.A. chs. 115 and 116. 
    Approving authority means the city council of the City of Willmar. 
    BOD means the quantity of oxygen, expressed in milligrams per liter, utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory conditions for five (5) days at a temperature of twenty (20) degrees Centigrade. The laboratory determinations shall be made in accordance with procedures set forth in Standard Methods. 
    Collection system means the system of sewers and appurtenances for the collection, transportation and pumping of domestic wastewater and industrial waste. 
    Debt retirement means the annual costs of principal and interest incurred by the city on the wastewater treatment facility. 
    Depreciation means funds set aside annually for: 
(1)  Purchase and installation of new equipment, or modifications to existing facilities, which will improve the operation and performance of the wastewater treatment facilities or wastewater pumping stations. 
(2)  Purchase of trucks and heavy equipment needed for operation and maintenance. 
(3)  Purchase of office and accounting equipment. 
    Director of public works means the Director of Public Works of the City of Willmar. 
    Domestic wastewater means water-borne wastes normally being discharged from the sanitary conveniences of dwellings, apartment houses, hotels, office buildings, factories and institutions, free of industrial wastes, and in which the average concentration of suspended solids is established at or below two hundred fifty (250) milligrams per liter and the BOD is established at or below two hundred fifty (250) milligrams per liter. 
    Industrial user means: 
(1)  Any entity as defined in the Standard Industrial Classification Manual, latest edition, that discharges wastewater to the public sewer system. 
(2)  Any user whose discharges, singly or by interaction with other wastes: contaminate the sludge of the wastewater treatment system, injure or interfere with the treatment process, create a public nuisance or hazard, have an adverse effect on the water's receiving wastewater treatment plant discharges, exceed normal domestic strength waste limitations, exceed normal residential unit volumes of wastewater. 
    Industrial waste means any water-borne solids, liquids or gaseous wastes other than domestic wastewater, resulting from, discharging from, flowing from or escaping from any commercial, industrial, manufacturing or food processing operation or process or from the development of any natural resource, or any mixture of these with water or domestic wastewater. 
    Industry means any nongovernmental, nonresidential user of publicly owned treatment works which is identified in the Standard Industrial Classification Manual, current, Office of Management and Budget, as amended and supplemented, under the following divisions: 
(1)  Division A, agriculture, forestry and fishing. 
(2)  Division B, mining. 
(3)  Division D, manufacturing. 
(4)  Division E, transportation, communications, electric, gas and sanitary services. 
(5)  Division I, services. 
    Normal domestic strength waste means wastewater that is primarily introduced by residential users, with a BOD concentration not greater than two hundred fifty (250) milligrams per liter, a total suspended solids (TSS) concentration not (TKN) concentrations not greater than forty (40) milligrams per liter, and total phosphorus (TP) concentrations not greater than five (5) milligrams per liter. 
    Operation and maintenance cost means expenditures made by the city in the operation and maintenance of its wastewater treatment facilities and wastewater pumping stations, consisting of and limited to the actual sums spent for each and all of the following purposes: 
(1)  Wages and salaries of operating, maintenance, clerical, laboratory and supervisory personnel, together with fringe benefits and premiums paid on such wages and salaries for the state workmen's compensation coverage and Public Employee's Retirement Act benefits. 
(2)  Electrical power. 
(3)  Chemicals, fuel and other operating supplies. 
(4)  Repairs to and maintenance of equipment. 
(5)  Premiums for hazard insurance. 
(6)  Premiums for insurance providing coverage against liability for the injury to persons or property. 
(7)  Rents and leasing costs. 
(8)  Operation, licensing and maintenance costs for trucks and heavy equipment. 
(9)  Consultant and legal fees. 
(10)  Replacement. 
    NPDES permit means a permit to discharge pollutants, obtained under the national pollutant discharge elimination system (NPDES) pursuant to M.S.A. ch. 115 and section 402(b) of the act. 
    Pass through means a discharge that exits the WWTF into waters of the state in quantities or concentrations that, alone or in conjunction with a discharge or discharges from other sources, is a cause of violating a requirement of any permit, rule, regulation or ordinance controlling, prohibiting, or limiting the release of pollutants from the WWTF into the environment, including an increase in the magnitude or duration of a violation. 
    pH means the logarithm (base 10) of the reciprocal of the hydrogen ion concentration expressed in moles per liter. It shall be determined by one (1) of the procedures outlined in Standard Methods. 
    Priority pollutants are any of the following listed substances, compounds or elements identified by the United States Environmental Protection Agency pursuant to Section 307 (A)(1) of the Act, as amended: 
Acenapthene; Acrolein; Acrylonitrile; Benzene; Benzidine; Carbon tetrachloride; (tetrachloromethane); Chlorobenzene; 1,2,4-trichlorobenzene; Hexachlorobenzene; 1,2-dichloroethane; 1,1,1-trichlorethane;     Replacement means expenditures for obtaining and installing equipment, accessories and appurtenances which are necessary during the design or useful life of the treatment works, whichever is longer, to maintain the capacity and performance for which such works were designed and constructed. 
    Sanitary sewer means a sewer that conveys domestic wastewater or industrial waste, or a combination of both, and into which stormwater, surface water and groundwater, or unpolluted industrial wastewater, are not intentionally passed. 
    Significant industrial user means any industrial user of the wastewater treatment facility: 
(1)  Who is subject to Categorical Pretreatment Standards under Title 40 CFR (Code of Federal Regulations), 40 CFR 403.6 and Title 40 CFR, Chapter I, subchapter N. Any industry that falls under these categories is considered a SIU whether or not it has process discharge to the collection system or wastewater treatment facilities; 
(2)  Who discharges twenty-five thousand (25,000) gallons per day or more of process wastewater to the collection system (excluding sanitary, noncontact cooling and boiler blow-down wastewater); 
(3)  Whose discharge flow or organic loading exceeds five (5) percent of the treatment facility's capacity; 
(4)  Whose waste contains a toxic pollutant in toxic amounts pursuant to section 307(a) of the act; 
(5)  Whose discharge has a significant effect, either singly or in combination with other contributing industries, on the wastewater disposal system, the quality of sludge, the system's effluent quality, or emissions generated by the treatment system; or 
(6)  Who is designated as such by the city on the basis that the industrial user has a reasonable potential for adversely affecting the operation of the collection system or wastewater treatment facilities, or violating any pretreatment standard or requirement. 
    Slug means any discharge of water or wastewater which, in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow, exceeds, for any period of duration longer than thirty (30) minutes, more than five (5) times the average twenty-four-hour concentration of flow during normal operation, and which adversely affects the collection or performance of the wastewater treatment works. 
    Standard Methods means the examination and analytical procedures set forth in the latest edition of Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater, as prepared, approved and published jointly by the American Public Health Association, American Water Works Association, and the Water Pollution Control Federation. 
    Storm sewer means a sewer which carries storm and surface drainage but excludes domestic wastewater and industrial wastes. 
    Superintendent means the superintendent of the wastewater treatment plant, who shall be in charge of and supervise the operations and functions of the wastewater treatment plant. 
    Surcharge means an additional charge related to industrial wastes being discharged by any user having excessive BOD or suspended solids in excess of two hundred fifty (250) milligrams per liter or TKN in excess of forty (40) mg/l or TP in excess of five (5) mg/l. 
    Suspended solids means solids that either float on the surface of or are in suspension in water, sewage or other liquids, and which are removable by a laboratory filtration device. Quantitative determination of suspended solids shall be made in accordance with procedures set forth in Standard Methods. 
    Total kjeldahl nitrogen or TKN means the sum of organic nitrogen, ammonia (NH3) and ammonium (NH4) in waste water. 
    Total phosphorus or TP means the sum of organic and orthophosphate in wastewater. 
    Total toxic organics is the summation of all quantifiable values greater than .01 milligrams per liter for the following toxic organics or elements identified by the United States Environmental Protection Agency pursuant to section 307(a)(1) of the act, as amended: 
Acenaphthene; Acrolein; Acrylonitrile; Benzene; Benzidine; Carbon tetrachloride (tetrachloromethane); Chlorobenzene; 1,2,4-trichlorobenzene; Hexachlorobenzene; 1,2-dichloroethane; 1,1,1-trichloroethane; Hexachloroethane; 1,1-dichloroethane; 1,1,2-trichloroethane; 1,1,2,2-tetrachloroethane; Chloroethane; Bis (2-chloroethyl) ether; 2-chloroethyl vinyl ether (mixed); 2-chloronaphthalene; 2,4,6-trichlorophenol; Parachlorometal cresol; Chloroform (trichloromethane); 2-chlorophenol; 1,2-dichlorobenzene; 1,3-dichlorobenzene; 1,4-dichlorobenzene; N-nitrosodi-n-propylamine; Pentachlorophenol; Phenol; Bis (2-ethylhexyl) phthalate; Butyl benzyl phthalate; Di-n-butyl phthalate; Di-n-octyl phthalate; Diethyl phthalate; Dimethyl phthalate; 1,2-benzanthracene; (benzo(a)anthracene); Benzo(a)pyrene(3,4-benzopyrene); 3,4-Benzofluroanthene 
(benzo(b)fluoranthene); 11,12-benzofluoranthene (benzo(k)fluoranthene); Chrysene; Acenaphthylene; Anthracene; 1,12-benzoperylene (benzo(ghi)perylene); Fluorene; Phenanthrene; 1,2,5,6-dibenzanthracene (dibenzo(a,h)anthracene; Indeno(1,2,3-cd) pyrene (2,3-o-phenlene pyrene); Pyrene; Tetrachloroethylene; Toluene; Trichlorethylene; Vinyl chloride (chloroethylene); 3,3-dichlorobenzidine; 1,1-dichloroethylene; 1,2-trans-dichloroethylene; 2,4-dichlorophenol; 1,2-dichloropropane(1,3-dichloropropene); 2,4-dimethylphenol; 2,4-dinitrotoluene; 2,6-dinitrotoluene; 1,2-diphenylhydrazine; Ethylbenzene; Fluoranthene; 4-chlorophenyl phenyl ether; 4-bromophenyl phenyl ether; Bis (2-chloroisopropyl) ether; Bis (2-chloroethoxy) methane; Methylene chloride (dichloromethane); Methyl chloride (chloromethane); Methyl bromide (bromomethane); Bromoform (tribromomethane); Dichlorobromomethane; Chlorsdibromomethane; Hexachlorobutadiene; Hexachlorocyclopentadiene; Isophorone; Naphthalene; Nitrobenzene; 2-nitrophenol; 4-nitrophenol; 2,4-dinitrophenol; 4,6-dinitro-o-cresol; N-nitrosodimethylamine; N-nitrosodimethylamine; Aldrin; Dieldrin; Chlordane (technical mixture and metabolites); 4,4-DDT; 4,4-DDE(p,p-DDX); 4,4-DDD(p,p-TDE); Alpha-endosulfan; Beta-endosulfan; Endosulfan sulfate; Endrin; Endrin aldehyde; Heptachlor; Heptachlor epoxide (BHC-hexachlorocyclohexane); Alpha-BHC; Beta-BHC; Gamma-BHC; Delta-BHC; (PCB-polychlorinated biphenyls); PCB-1242 (Arochlor 1242); PCB-1254 (Arochlor 1254); PCB-1221 (Arochlor 1221); PCB-1232 (Arochlor 1232); PCB-1248 (Arochlor 1248); PCB-1260 (Arochlor 1260); PCB-1016 (Arochlor 1016); Toxaphene; 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin (TCDD).
